Early Access Review

The game is generally good yes but be warned there are somethings I wish they would fix.
A. THE HIT-BOXES!: I have to directly hit the enemy and if my shots go past it then I don't do damage. That definitely needs fixing. Try it yourself you will see why. (If your reading this, and its been fixed, then disregard that)

B. Enemy Detecting: I cant tell an enemy from a friend, the next thing I know a tiny little bug incapacitated me. The game is spacey so why not add a techno enemy detector or something spacey? It would be nice to have done in those 28 days before the MEGA UPDATE!

C. Objective: OK so in Terraria (Not related just thought this was a lot like it) you knew if your friends told you or not that you had to slay something and survive through the world. Well this game is very spacey and from what I have played this game needs an objective bad. VERY bad.

Now here is a list of what I officially think of this very game! Trust me this should cover why I enjoy this game so much.

Well I have to say the game has very good potential. And it has Terraria data so that is kind of exciting, if they do read this I hope they know that I am routing for them and hoping they prosper and flourish in their glory, they have made a master piece's outlining, now can they finish the painting and how that is my main question in this all. reviewText:
First, I love this game, I loved terraria, and I definitely believe this game has so much potential just like terraria does. Throughout all of the builds I have loved this game, they tried a bunch of new ways to have the player level up and go through the story and I gotta say I like this one the most.

Hey, I know the game has some issues running right now, but I have confidence in this team, they have been developing the game for the longest time now and they are always improving it, if you don't like it right now, that is fine, but maybe in a month or two you can come back and check it out again to find it to be more than satisfactory.

This game has amazing art, cool combat, and a crazy terrain. Only boss I found was Omegatron and he was pretty awesome to fight, but just imagine the other bosses they made.

Again, there is some optimization needed in the game, but the game is fresh out of launch and perhaps this isn't what they expected to happen at launch and I bet they are working on it right now, so just take it with a grain of salt, ok?
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Yeah, when this game was in EA it was a little rough around the edges, but it was still a game, which I can say is more than most can say at this point, but it's out and 1.0. Does it still have a few rough spots? Sure, but what game doesn't on initial release, but they are working hard on it, to fix what is going on, and are very connected with the community giving us regular updates on whats up.

The game is built around the idea of exploration, terraforming and expansion. Each of which is handled very well.

The experience system that has been added in replacing the old way of researching is MUCH better and a welcome addition, as is all the UI cleanup that has been done.

One thing I love about this game is there is nothing you pick up that is completely worthless (except building structure tiles if you don't plan to build with them). You can use Dirt, Stone, Biomass, jelly, shark stuff, to make guns, armor, jetpacks, tools and ammo.

The Game is deep, and has more content in it than I will ever have time to discover, but for those of you whom have enjoyed Terraria, Starbound and Crea this is a welcome addition to the collection.

Like I said, it's not a perfect game, but it still a heck of a lot of fun, I'd give it a 8/10.

(Also be very warry of the negative reviews, most were done while it was in EA and a lot has changed since then, or many have been posted since it went live, but they have 0.0 hours of play time since it has.)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirstly, the combat is annoying and clunky, especially when all the enemies are darting around erratically making it infuriating to try and hit them; and when you do eventually land a shot, the enemy (in the first zone, less than 20 minutes in) is totally immune to your weapon, and firing back homing explosives which are very had to evade or shoot down. The AI is clairvoyant, always knowing where to aim at any moment, and the explosive weapon of one of the first three enemies you will face can break large holes into your base, allowing the rest to hit you directly, killing a player obscenely quickly. Secondly, the crafting is on a tech tree, requiring spelunking with useless tier-1 equipment to try to unlock tier-2 and so on, sadly, the depth you can reach is restricted, and a player will often never find anything before death forces them to their respawn point. The crafting is clunky and difficult, the UI is a battle to navigate with almost no quick access to the comically named hotbar"

reviewText:
I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #54 - Edge of Space

You'll get an immediate sense of the quirky writing in Edge of Space as you start by having a conversation with a talking shark.  There isn't that much of a story to tell, just that your spaceship crashed and now you are stranded on a planet.  The writing is definitely tongue-in-cheek.

I liked how the game began, and appreciated that it wasn't too difficult to begin with.  Although I do wish they had explained some things a little better.  The game includes a tutorial video" that I felt was kind of a shortcut
date: as opposed to just better integrating a tutorial into the game.  Still
recommended: the first set of quests you get involve gathering various components to then craft into items
hoursPlayed: which is a pretty major part of the gameplay.\n\nI wish the controls were better.  I found mining to be frustrating at times.  You use a mining pick that you aim with your mouse.  But the aim is weird at times.  I kept wanting to just point my mouse cursor at a block to mine.  But the aim is actually based on the position of your cursor relative to a point on your body in order to determine direction.  This means sometimes
voteText: even when your mouse cursor is on a block
helpfulPercent: the aim is actually causing the laser to hit a different block.  It's a minor annoyance but mining is such a major part of the gameplay that it definitely adds up.\n\nIf you've played Terraria
votesHelpful: then you'll pretty much know exactly what to expect here.  It's pretty hard not to consider this game a knock off.  There are some minor differences with crafting
votesTotal: like the way you can use different items to fill a recipe.  But as a whole the gameplay feels extremely familiar.   I don't hold it against Edge of Space for being a knock off
votesFunny: but when you're borrowing from another game
commentsCount: you should at least make some notable improvements.  And it really doesn't feel that way.  And when you add the fact that Terraria is cheaper ($14.99 vs. $9.99 regular prices)
column16: I really can't recommend this game unless you've just played Terraria to death and want to scratch that itch with a different game."

reviewText:
EoS plays less smooth than Terraria or Starbound, the controls are kinda clunky. It takes some patience to get used to the gameplay. And there are some annoying things like snails that push you away.

The research system in EoS is very nice, it feels like leveling your character, except not by getting better stats, but by gaining crafting knowledge. There's alot of different crafting brances with each their own tiers to research to the max.

If you like this genre and you're looking for something new, try EoS. It's worth your time and money.

reviewText:
I have a split review about this game, (9/19/15 edit NO LONGER SPLIT) so below you will find my pros about EoS.

Pros:
Amazing graphics, sure there is better, but the graphics amplify the futuristic feel of the game rather then the classic 8-bit.

Kind playerbase, I have been to many a server on EoS and only 1-2 of them have had a non-userfriendly community to come along with them, but those that do i mostly delete from my server list.

Understanding Devs, unlike most early acces games, EoS has devs who always respond to complaints and try to fix them. Most of what usaully turns me away from early acces games is the devs forget about the players after a bit and turn the game into a money grab for them, but thankfully Eos's devs show no sign of doing so. (thanks guys)

Addictive gameplay, EoS has a feel that you have to keep on going to the next thing, boss after boss, domain after domain.

The fact that you have categories instead of a specific item being needed for every recipe. In my opinion, this really helps because you can swap clay for dirt for mud for rock etc. This helps because you dont have to grind your way through the world looking for specific resources.

It has a story, unlike most games (except starbound) this game follows a story that explains why you are randomly stuck on a planet with a cryopod as a respawn point.

Cons: As of 9/19/15 i cannot think of any cons

The advertising video is a complete lie: 9/19/15 edit: not anymore!!! the trailer pretty much sums up the gameplay (congratulations to the devs for finnaly completing it)

The sections of the research list (my hotkey is L) of Experimental armor, Assualt armor, and Recon armor: 9/19/15 edit: no longer relevant =x

Also you cant get structure blocks for a base until a few hours in: 9/19/15 edit: FIXED: can get this almost immediately after creating the world

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't get me wrong the game is solid already,  but even at this point early access,  the base game just doesn't feel very involving.  You start out in a game with a spawn point and are given lots of blueprints to activate then craft.  Where I get pretty annoyed and usually give up is the whole downward scrolling aspect of the game.  To reach the first 'layer' of a surface, you need to drop down,  which requires building stairs back up to the initial block of dirt you spawn in to presumably build your starting base.

Getting back to the whole verticle scrolling aspect of the game.  Going up and and down all the time requires building lots of stairs and frequent use of your jetpack.  The problem is, it recharges extremely slowly,  resulting in a lot of time just waiting to use it.   Lighting is also trickier than in other survival games:  there's a few flareguns and torches to be placed,  but they all require using the crafting menu,  which is tedious. For example, to craft an item you need to select the materials you want to use first,  sometimes there's a huge list of materials you need and if you are missing one, you'll have to re-select all of them again if you want to try and craft again.   A lot of the time you'll find yourself in the dark trying to climb out of a pit of some sort, and hope you don't accidently fall further downwards to certain doom.

Speaking of tedious,  everything just feels tedious to me about the game.  Mining is about as exciting as watching blocks smoke from heat before turning into collectable ores.  Crafting requires dragging a blueprint to your inventory slots, selecting the slot,  holding left click to activate the blueprint,  then right clicking the inventory slot to remove the blueprint.  This is just a typical example of how something is done in this game and honestly I don't feel like any of it is as intuitive as it should be.

Combat is also pretty sleepy.  You shoot enemies,  and they die.  There's no real weight to the combat and it's just not very gratifying.

Overall tho, the game does feel solid as I say.  Personally I just fall asleep trying to figure something out,  but that's just me.  Many will find the game appealing because there is much to do and there's a lot of content,  so if the aforementioned things don't bug you, feel free to dive in.

Quick Review:

Edge of space is quite a relaxing game. It obviously lacks of fun and ecxiting things to do but it has its simple charm of just simplistic things to do, I'm sure you'll have a good time if you don't compare to terraria and starbound. (unless you hate these 2D kind of games... why would you even consider buying this if thats the case....)

Long Review:

Lets start with describing what its missing and what needs to change. CONS:
First of all, as everyone would say about this game, is that its various inventory and crafting pop ups" are complete rubbish. They need to change all of these because has it is for now
date: you have to press around 7 different keys to open 7 different things that literaly take up ALL you screen. And btw it also doesn't pause the game so you'll be sure to be killed if you don't pay attention. So all this inventory bussiness needs to be sorted out.\nYou'll also have a hard time getting used to this weird new crafting mechanic they use. Even though it isn't the worst
recommended: it sure is quite different... I personally don't mind it because it forces you to go out of your base and mine and kill stuff for experience. You then spend this experience on different types of weapons or armor. Tbh the armor and weapons they have at the moment are quite boring. There is nothing special about them so you'll end up just picking what does more damage and what benifits you the most. They will need to make each weapon type more special and more ecxiting.\nFinally the envirnment is also quite dull. A lot of what this game lacks of is just fun and cool stuff to do

reviewText:
I waited a long time to review this game, mainly because I don't like or want to contribute to negative reviews.

I acquired this game in pre-Alpha back in 2013 and it was a rather RAW version of the game back then. The forums were kicking on the main webpage and wheels were turning with update ideas and the direction of the game. Fast forward 2-3 years and there is a lot of development, a lot of change, and a game that has been finished. There were many character wipes and world wipes along the way = That was to be expected. I bought it on pre-order before early access, and played for about 6-8 months through early access, so a few save wipes isn't a huge deal.

However, I think another user said it best  I think the negative reviews are born mostly out of frustration with how long the game took to get from early access to release."

Here we are three years later with a game that is no longer in Early Access but still has clunky controls and somewhat of a grind feel. However - it has come a long way
date: and if you came  here NOT expecting to grind in order to craft and survive
recommended: I don't know what you were expecting.\n\nI played some of the most recent updates and will update my review from not recommended to recommended
hoursPlayed: but with a disclaimer attached: This game still doesn't feel 100% to me. But
voteText: Terraria never did either - far from it - and everyone loves to compare this title to Terraria. Terraria was lacking in story line

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game that came before Starbound, and if you took Terraria and Starbound and inbreed you would get this game.

3/11/14 content and prior

Pro's

Cheap price, and as of this review you get a bonus copy for a family or friend.
Nice backgrounds for biomes.

Sounds: Not Starbound and not as enjoyable as Terraria, but it fits the sci fi theme.

Jetpacks: Jetpacks!


Cons

Tutorial, Doors fail to open, chest have the wrong things in it. Command help comes a little too late.

Items that don't work, example starting gun you make does 1 damage a hit but enemies take 0 damage. You die before you can kill the weakest of things

Usual glitches that I will not list because this is an early access.


So in final I would tell anyone to give it a try while its cheap and you get the bonus copy, after that go watch some let's play of it or perhaps some one streaming on Twitch.

reviewText:
The game is out of Early Access now and I've played what I consider to be the majority of the content in the game, so I'm updating my review.

This game's pretty good and I do recommend it for a good 20 hours of playtime.

Pros:
Scifi setting is nice
Goofy humour is good and prevalent throughout the game if you're into that kind of thing
Game runs smooth for me and I've encountered few bugs since coming out of early access
A lot of different blocks and placeables for building bases
A lot of different items and armours
Dungeons are a lot of fun
Music is great and matches the mood
NPCs that give quests
Easy to fast travel between bases

Cons:
Nothing to really do in the 3rd biome but grind for materials to build end game gear.  Also, there doesn't appear to be a dungeon in the 3rd biome
Light radius is small (spamming torches helps but that's just annoying)
Weapons never really get powerful, even the Death Dealer takes multiple hits on spike balls (personal con, I like to feel powerful when I get to the end of a game)
Still a lot of stuff that feels unfinished (many items share sprites, no dungeon in 3rd biome)
I didn't try multiplayer but it sounds like it takes quite a bit of work to set up a server and to get people to join

They are still working on the game, but at a much slower pace.  I hope they make another game because I have enjoyed Edge of Space for what it is and I would like to see something new using what they have learned developing this game.


OLD REVIEW:
I would recommend the game at the stage it is currently at if they sold it as a finished game.  So, the fact that they are still working on it and improving it all the time makes it an easy recommendation.  The devs are very active in the forums and constantly updating the game.  One of the devs even broadcasts on twitch sometimes while wearing a shark suit.  This game has come a long way from its original early access release and is going to go a lot farther.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Early Access Review* *Not final review*
This game is a 2D mining sandbox game, but it's not a generic clone of Terraria, but it does feel like a clone. First off, combat only consists of guns right now, this is quite annoying, but the amount of guns is pretty good. Crafting is very complex, you can substitute some materials for others, but this also makes the crafting system feel slow and clunky, which I hope this is fixed later on. The developers update the game VERY often, and make changes based on community feedback, like an early access game should. I recommend this game based on sheer content alone, but buyers beware, it's early access, there ARE bugs.

reviewText: If you are the type of person who is ok with having to remember on your own every detail of every inch of your world as you explore it, or are one of those people who can go exploring, end up in a running barrle, and die and know exactly how to get back to where you got by sheer accident than mayby you will like this game, for the rest of us I would say don't bother.  there is no in game world map, just a mini map.  it is entirely possible to fall through a series of areas and get completely lost.  there is no way to see where you were to get back there, you have to memorize everything, and for people like me that play once in a while you have no idea where everything was.  the nature of this games series of floating islands is what really inflames the problem.  unlike in games like terraria, a great deal of your time will be exploring by traveling through empty sky to see what is out there.  if you miscalculate your fall angle for the return trip you will miss what you found completely.  it is similar to trying to recreate a randm painting as a connect the dots puzzle when you can only see the dots your pencil tip is next to.

I enjoyed playing this game.  It has a lot of work to be done to get to the final stages, and it's clearly an early access project but seems to be getting there.

Would probably recommend it to others.

reviewText:
So, ill start with addressing the mixed views.. most of the bad comments you see about this game are from back when the game was in pre-alpha.. since then this amazing team has made this game beautiful and have really come a long way.. I should know I played this back before it was even on steam, but thats my opinion.  AND dont let my time played on steam fool you, trust me I have hours soaked into this game.

Now for the pros and cons.

-PROS-
-tons of weapons
-tons of armor
-lots of really cool mounts, such as SPACE RAPTORS, gaint crabs, mechs and gunships, even ones that help you build and mine!
-lots of really cool decor and important building items
-has a really cool power system in which you can root a power supply to your lights, doors, and even crafting stations.
-a great number of really cool enemies to fight from flying jellyfish to polarbears with artillery cannons on their backs.
-has dungeons with some rather awesome boss fights
-3 types of armor, fighter, builder and explorer, each pretty self explanatory.
-constant updates which always fix problems and bring in awesome new toys.
-as is,  the game has a ton of fun content that will keep you busy for hours.

I could keep going but I think you get the point.

-CONS-

-You dont own this game
-has a few bugs, nothing really GAME breaking, except for the UI problems, opening menus and such lag the menus out, this while really game breaking is being broken down on as we speak, so in a week or two you can most likely ignore this.
-needs a bit more upbeat music, mostly for events etc.

Well honestly thats all I can think of.. if you are a fan of games like terraria or starbound, or just a fan of 2d games where you can build, then give this game a go its great!  With the speed of updates and endless content they can put out for it im sure this game will keep going strong for a long time, once they fix that UI lag... good bye social life.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros - Good game so far. Playable. Hours of game play. Survival. Dont have to remember Crafting. Music. Can make anything with anything. You have the right to record EdgeOfSpace I believe. Has Mutiplayer. Tutorial on basics at the beginning. Achievements(Not a good thing to the game, just something I like about games).

Cons - Needs bug fixes, and more ores to find early on. Crabs are too OP at the beginning. Run out of energy too fast. YOu dont regain Energy as fast as you loose it. Everything wants to kill you. No tutorial on how to make Energy work with the doors or CommandCenter(which i believe will be added?). No trading Cards(Not a downside, just something most steam games have, which I believe this game will have shortly later).

Personal Review - Ive only had this game for 1-2 days, but I can tell you, this game is a great game and has a lot of potential for a early access game. Look forward to the updates and how it will improve to be a better game than what it is now. I strongly recomend this game if you are looking for a game like Terraria and/or Starbound to play with your friends. The energy/electricty system is a little hard to understand first, but I hope it will get better with the updates. With mutiplayer you can get things done a whole lot faster, as ive played with my three other friends. If you want a survival game I recomend this game. The music is great, and has a spaceish feel to it. Mutiplayer is easy to use, just open your ports, and get the IP, boom youre in. Playabe, and has hours of game play just to get the basic things.

I Love this game so far, and I am looking forward to the updates to make this game even better! I am planning to make a gameplay series of this game, show the updates, and how to do things in the game.
Keep up the good work Devs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has come a long way. I bought in on a whim in my early terraira burn-out phase. Wasn't much then, but the developers have been working hard to improve the game and it shows. Countless patches later this game could launch today and it would get solid reviews. I recommend this one to anyone with a love for rouge likes and has a taste for the sci-fi our fathers used to enjoy. Outside of that, this is at it's core a mining/crafting game. Nothing special to remark outside of differences from other games in genre. Overall not bad compared to other offerings either when it comes to controls, content and depth. Sure, it's not on the same scale as Starbound, and nothing is as polished as terraira, but this game has character and immersion. The rough edges of this work in progress are limited to a lack  of good interface and general tutorials that leave much to be desired. I haven't truly logged enough hours to speak about end game, but I want you to know that I havent regret my purchase since day one (well over a year before this review). Check it out, I think you'll probably end up feeling the same.

reviewText:
PROS:

Progression
-I appreciate the progression in this game, it's not something where you get to end-game gear in one day. I still haven't got to the end-game yet, in fact, I barely even started. According to my character, I have learned less than 10% of everything you can learn in the game.

Progression Part 2
-This may seem grindy, but Edge of Space made this slow progression curve actually fun. They broke up the progression in a way where there's branches you pick, like armor crafting, weapon crafting, base construction and even pet creation, and there's 15 tiers of progression in each branch, each successing tier costing more knowledge points. Everything gives you knowledge points to spend to progress further, and the deeper you dig into the planet, the more points you earn.

NPC's and Crafting Stations
-There's NPC's that hand out quests, which keep you busy, some requiring harder to achieve materials than others. And on top of these NPC's, there's a large amount of crafting stations, requiring you to have some kind of base. There's also command centers, which provide power to nearby devices which require power. It's a neat system I don't see in too many games.

CONS:

(Let's be honest here, no game is perfect. So, let's get to the chase, and say the things I've noticed and dislike about this game. Also, keep in mind that everything I have said is my opinion)

Textures
-Quite a few items in the game share the same texture, like Soft Chitin and Penguin Explosives. These 2 items are very different, but they look exactly the same, and it's a little annoying. This is one example of items sharing the same texture, and there are a few more instances.

Multiplayer
-Multiplayer is a bit janky. When me and my friend played on a server I hosted, we noticed you can have only 1 of each Quest NPC in the world, and command centers (They provide power), cannot be placed anywhere near each other. So, what I'm saying is you and your friend have to share a base, or your friend has to live far away, and one of you has to walk all the way to the other player's base to talk to the NPC's. Also, the quests are independent, but at least the dungeons you can go to are publicly accesible which slighly makes up for this. But all in all, I was far ahead of my friend, and had all the quest NPC's, which ruined his experience a little bit, because we were independently progressing.

All in all, this game has more pros than cons in my opinion, and makes for a great game. If you don't feel comfortable paying $14.99, then wait for a sale. I got this game for only $4.99 around Christmas, and trust me, if you think this game isn't worth $15, then it most certainly is worth $5, because this game has potential for hours of enjoyment!

-KLuebbert

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has potential, however. dropping material and items on death is a frustrating turnoff, especially when the mobs are really overpowered to start off (the nuking jetpack things and the hard to hit red jelly fish, not to mention the ground bugs that destroy a fourth of my health per contact, sometimes juggling me), killing me over and over as I try to reclaim my items. The aiming system could use some tweaking or the enemies should move slower because it is very difficult to hit them. Im not sure if killing jely metroids is the only way to make torches, but it is very tedious with how the starting weapon is so maybe an alternative and easier method of crafting torches could be adopted if there is not one allready.

The concept is really nice, its good to see a scifi approach to this kind of sidescrolling adventure. I am looking forward to future imrovements and hpoing at least some of the above problems will be addressed.

This review is subject to change with future updates.

reviewText:
After extensive playing of Edge of Space since the release I decided to rewrite my review.

Pros:

Sci-fi setting with a good intro video explaining why you are on a planet that’s hostile and heck bent on killing you.

I love the sci-fi graphics, and the look of the broken planet landscape.

Excellent array of items to craft, in fact, the list is HUGE, including three different sets of armor (each with their own upgrade tree), all kinds of different weapon types, and a lot of other things that give my love of farming resources, and collecting new, interesting bits and pieces, a lot of reasons to feel content.

A very large selection of base building decorations, workstations, defenses, etc. And yes, the advanced items require extensive farming and playing the game to gather enough resources to make, which some might feel is grindy, but I feel motivates me to keep exploring and mining for “a few more minutes” and then turns out to be two-three hours of game time I didn’t even know slipped by when I glance at the clock.

I’ve heard a lot of negatives about the user interface, but personally I see nothing wrong with it, and you can see it demonstrated in action via screen-shots, youtube videos, and streams, so it’s not like the developers are trying to hide something… If it doesn’t interfere with my game-play and fun, I don’t see how it’s a problem.

Lots of biomes, and mobbies, and some good humorous moments.

Tons of new areas to explore, and lots to keep you busy.

Developers that are getting the kinks worked out as fast as possible, and they are very active and responsive in the forums begging those with issues to send them logs so they can fix any issues for everybody else.

I’ve put a ton of time in and I am thoroughly enjoying myself, because I find the game both extensive and challenging.

I myself haven’t crashed even once, and though I experience lag here and there it only happens for me after playing for several hours straight. My computer is an Asus Rog Gaming Laptop, win 10, and I have an nvidia card.

The mini patches since 1.0 hit have improved the game a lot, in my opinion.

Active Devs that really want this game to succeed and are willing to do whatever it takes — though they get knocked around a lot by players that seem unwilling to give them time to hear and fix any issues that might be present…

Cons:

The Lead Dev has said the game was designed more for multiplayer, so mobs tend to spawn in waves that can overwhelm a single playing character… After reading that bit of info, I was sad, because I look at these games as something I wish to spend a lot of time with soloing. Like in Terraria when I played with a friend he wanted to kill this boss, and that boss, and I wanted to just find resources. I never played with anyone again, though once I got to Moon Lord I lost interest, because I realized that fight wasn’t balanced for single player at all (my opinion).

EOS needs some patches to iron out the kinks, and I bet my life SO WILL Terraria Otherworld when it’s released. Even Terraria has had at least a half dozen mini patches since 1.3 hit, and I don’t see anyone knocking Terraria for it… And Starbound will continue to see many updates and patches before and after its 1.0 version hits… Whenever that might happen — sooner than later, me hopes!

Players rush to leave negative feedback, rather than logging the problem and helping the Devs get a handle on it. They have asked and asked for player input via logs, but some grumpy, unhelpful players would rather sink their chance at sales than help get the game working perfectly for everyone.

The game is extensive and resource gathering takes a long, long time. And some ingredients are very hard to find and farm — like Penguin parts and even Headhunter parts, and though I love to farm resources, even I wish these dropped more often…

Sometimes things feel unfair, unbalanced, such as weapon upgrades that don’t do much to make you feel like the mobbies are being hurt… I swear there was a penguin laughing at me at a Penguin Rave — it was hysterical, this little penguin dancing at a Rave as I’m shooting him, pew pew for half a minute…

It seems New Players find the beginning confusing, and perhaps because the game is so extensive more time should have been put into a longer, more engaging tutorial, with an option to skip it for more advanced players…

Final thoughts:

Personally I’m enjoying my time in the game, and though I have a large library, it keeps pulling me back with that one more node feeling, and I wake up excited to play and find new areas and new upgrades, etc. Some might not like gathering, farming games, and if the game is balanced around MP, I think MP should have been a bigger priority, as I believe a lot of complaints have stemmed from the MP community, AND I feel us solo players might not find the game as satisfying in the later stages, if the game really cannot be completed single player (which I’ve no idea if it can or cannot, but I’m hoping!!!)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

November 28th, 2014

Picked this up during a sale. I own Terraria and Starbound but the latter left me burned with it's launch and follow through by the developers, but this isn't about that.

I'd been interested in Edge of Space for some time and had it on my Wishlist for a couple months before finally picking it up. A quick look through the history of the games shows I missed some of the blunder years the game held and am playing it after a UI and tier revamp so I can't comment on anything prior to the date above.

The game looks good, though I wish there were more customization items for characters, the style they've presented works well and I had no probably playing my marathon session of the game these past 2-3 days (17 hours) and the music is pretty darn good as well. Normally I listen to my own music collection during these types of games but I left the background BGM on and didn't grow to hate it.

The controls are smooth as well and how you can move is really limited to your gear and how well you can control your jet pack, using weapons can be tricky sometimes however. The game has a few different weapon types in its starter tier from the basic automatic rifle, sniper rifle, and mortar launcher. I've found myself using the sniper rifle and mortar exclusively. You have unlimited ammo but there is a reload timer but that's not why I don't use the automatic, the main reason is damage and difficulty hitting enemies. I played exclusively in a local hosted server with friends and there were times were you can't hit an enemy due to their size, movement, and shots just passing through (most likely due to the server lagging) so we found more success with the area damage of the mortar and taking the risk with the sniper rifle.

Crafting is pretty extensive as well. There are three armor types and many branches of crafting to skill up" by using Science XP gained from mining
recommended: and hunting monsters (which is the best gainer later on) and unlike Terraria and Starbound the dungeons aren't found in the world but you rather transport to them after gaining enough coordinates to get to them. Once you enter the dungeon the rules change
hoursPlayed: you can't use your mining laser or jet pack. Having these taken away really changes how you go against an enemy as you now have to time your jumping and can't block or tunnel away from an enemy (or through a stage) and personally I feel is nice change. Unfortunately I haven't seen the dungeon boss yet as during the dungeon we had problems with the game failing to load or players games blanking to grey in the dungeon.\n\nOverall however
voteText: I am really pleased with the purchase and look forward to future updates with the game. It does have a learning curve and some of the UI elements are weird (I've hit escape hoping to clear a open menu more times than I can count
helpfulPercent: it doesn't work) but overall at it's current stage it's fun and playable."
votesHelpful: November 28, 2014
votesTotal: true

reviewText: Dear god this game is strange. I find that the more I play it the more I enjoy it. But god it can be frustrating. There IS $15 of true fun here. It's just that too much of your time will be spent reading tutorials and figuring out unintuitive mechanics.\n\nLeveling up your gear and completing tasks is where the fun is. It truly is. reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you played all you could of Terraria and Starbound and absolutely love the sandbox genre of games then you will love Edge of Space. This game combine many of the elements of Terraria with an Edge of Space trim to it. The gameplay itself is similar to Terraria, but with a Starbound spacey theme. The game is unique in its own way. Game music is good, better than starbound but not as cool as Terraria. The game is more complex then Terraria and Starbound which can deter players who play it for the first time.

The tutorial explains the basic controls and concepts of the game, but in my opinion, more could have been done to explain the game mechanics for crafting.

You have to read your codex entries after the tutorial to figure out what you need to do. Once you do that the game becomes very fun to play. Explore, craft, fight... All is open to your disposal.

This game is still in beta, the developers are constantly patching the game and adding new content. The game only gets better from here.

reviewText:
Because Edge of space is out of early access I have decided to do a new review!  (please don't hit me again)


Edge of space is like Terraria in the general gist of things.

Many things however do differ.  In example you are in space in a semi futuristic setting.

1.  The tutorial" is not as god awful as last time and is easy enough to get it done.

2. The gameplay Kind of interesting the prospect of research and what you can do with it looks like it could grant some fun.

3. The graphics seem to be done by a few different people because they have slightly different art styles and overall design choices but over all get the job done.  However I think if they made the graphics more pixilated (Double or triple of terraria) the game would look and even run better.

4. The sounds are okay a bit cartoonish but the game is not the most serious.

5. The over all optimization of the game is better than a month ago but still needs work (Still playable on medium end machines) it runs and I can do things without it crashing in a god awful tutorial then refusing to start up again!

6. The price is a bit high I would say 14.99 is too steep for the game.  Even the current sale price of 10.94 is.  7 bucks would probably be a good range for the game so wait for a sale if you want it.

Over all I give the game a 6/10 but if a few patches fixing fps and screen tearing ( I tried on two very different computers and it happened on them both) came out it would be a 7/10


"

reviewText:
This one is pretty hard for me to judge objectively, as it was given by a now-gone Significant Other.

As such, I've desperately tried to like the game and pushed myself to give it more chances.

Now, with that in mind - The game has potential. There's some really great ideas in there as well as a unique art style (Though given the size of the sprites, I can't imagine there's much modding going on with people skilled enough to pull it off).

The problem is, as always, execution. Edge of Space feels very empty, despite its vast size, and there's not much to really  do other than Dig deeper
date: grind for better gear". The controls feels pretty floaty
recommended: and the gathering mechanics tend to get very weird when you want to mine a block right in front of you. Their attempts at humor are dry and fall flat on its face
hoursPlayed: as I've come to expect of indie games lately. Also
voteText: on top of frequent bugs and crashes

Enemy frequency and damage scale up disproportionally to your ability to defend yourself.\n\nSo what DO I like about the game? The crafting system is quite brilliant - Much like the (newly released at the moment of writing) Fallout 4

I've had it early access for quite some time now and was a bit afraid when the updates stopped coming, then all of a sudden BAM they put out the king of updates. I cane safely say this game is well worth the price especially if you like metroidvania exploration platformers. The interface takes some getting used to, but works very well once you do get used to it. It actually makes quite a lot of sense for something so far stretched from similar games.

Really honestly give this a chance, it's got a lot of potential and they are certainly doing their best to make us happy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very enjoyable game even though it is still under its earliest of development stages.
I currently have played the Tutorial and replayed the Tutorial, during three different stages of the BETA.
I have also played the first accessible world Acheao and had much fun even though the BETA often changes things that can both make and break the game!
Uniquely, everything has remained stable, everything playable, and the only problem is the bugs that are few in number and worked out with every update of the BETA.
And every update has added either new items, craftables, creatures, events, or even progression forms.
I'm enjoying the BETA. I will enjoy the game when it leaves BETA too. It is a lot like Starbound, but set in a different dimension with slightly differents rules, laws, and phsyics.
Oh, btw, if anything, you can customize your character to be a human, space kitten, cyborg, android, as well as being tenchologically altered, influenced by a slime symbiote, and more, so it all ends up really cool with character customization! Starbound has its races, EdgeOSpace has its many bizarre character feature combinations, inventing your own race and what not is easy (its only aesthetic though)!
I'll mention new things in my reccomendation as they come up... for now expect the occasional character wipe and the rarer world wipe as they alter and add things to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll start by saying that this game is fairly fun, but only if you like Terraria and Starbound type gameplay.  The game starts you off in the wilderness wearing some basic light armour, a jetpack, and a rifle in-hand.  Using your laser pick you can mine out the natural resources of the world, and using your rifle you can blast the natural fauna of the world.

At first you only know a handful of recipes, so as you go you will build data disks to unlock more recipes and more data in order to advance even further.  Unlike in say Terraria, you don't know every recipe off the bat, and unlike in say Starbound, you don't have to deconstruct or kill a boss to learn new recipes.

The game seems simple and easy, until you get hit by a random event, in which case you might end up losing all of your clones in a matter of minutes as an unrelenting anomally continually destroys you as soon as you spawn.  For this reason, it's very much recommended to upgrade your gear as soon as you can.  Good luck!

reviewText:
Hello guys and girls, I am long over due for my thoughts on this game.

Lets get started shall we, I am amongst the first people who Green Lit this game and helped it out during its earlier iterations. This game has come a long way from where it once was, and only a few of us can attest to this because we come from an opinion that goes back to early alpha. On here it says I put 13.8 hours into it, but off of steam I had actually put 60+ hours into it. That was all mainly dedicated to testing out the new builds as they were being released and the new systems. This game went from being hard to figure out, to hard as nails, and then an awesome tutorial came through. Guess what, they kept up with the new tutorials making them more stream lined and easier for new players to pick up and play. Mind you, the tutorials at the very beginning were not nooby friendly, but they fixed that, and that was all based on players feedback.

From personal experiences, this game is a lot of fun and offers a lot to the player base at an extremely low price. These guys have worked day and night to bring a better experience to the table with each major update coming out with new fixes and added crafting recipes down to materials. More feedback is always a must when it comes to the on going production of a title, especially a creation one. StarBound, Terraria and Edge Of Space offer different experiences all together and yet each one has worked on content for each other to help promote one another. Edge Of Space for me is a gem in itself and it shouldn't be looked over because someone elses troll review.

Instead of trolling why don't you just go and tell the developers what is wrong? Because that would make to much sense I guess, give this game a try, 10. bucks isn't a bad deal and you are getting way more then that back in the content that is currently available. I give this game     awesome out of awesome""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do recommend this game if you go into it knowing it's early access and not a complete game yet. That said it feels it has potential to be amazing. Starbound and Terraria had a baby, one where you think someone may have cheated on the other with Super Metroid. Controls and seem to handle well and be responsive, the issue is no real way to set up items to hotkeys so have to scroll through a list of items to get to the desired weapon/gadget. I assume this is something that will be taken care of at some point.  Environments looks nice and sharp, music helps sink you into the world,  and you start off with a jetpack. Not a easy game but After the little bit I have played, I'm sure it will be a great game.

Edit: New patch added the ability to assign items to 1-8 =)  nice!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a good chunk of potential. Of course, some stuff could be changed, but overall it has a good plot. It's like Terraria in some ways, aside from the content. (It has Terraria content in it, but that isnt my point.) Terraria and EoS have similarities, and those similarities are:

- 2-D
- Plot (This more relates to Starbound's plot, but its the basic idea.)

Those are the only similarities I can see right now. They have differences; many, as a matter of fact, and some of those differences are:

- EoS has people with longer legs
- EoS has no servers as far as I know of
- EoS involves spaceships

There is one thing I would like to change, although people may disagree with what I want changed, and that's ok, but you may as well continue looking. That one thing I want them to do is:

Reduce complexity; this game is a bit too complex. It has a good plot, and it has a good start, but it's too complex to do. Of course, I only just started this game, but it would help if you made it simpler, and easier for players to grasp control of what they can do.

Overall Rating: 7.5/10 - Acceptable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will keep this short and sweet, 8/10

good:

multi leveled world, deeper than terraria
balanced resource scrounging, nothing is handed to the player
an absolutely unforgiving survival situation, where one step can and will kill you.

Bad:

the tech tier is off a bit, making it nearly insane to get the stuff to explore the lower levels of the world.
The inability to move your spawn point. It wouldn't even need to be moved, if there was a way to remove the tiles underneath it.
The combat damage is way to OP, 90+ damage from flying jellyfish is a bit much.

But none of the bad things listed should detract you from trying this great game out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edge of Space (EoS) has just entered Early Access and is now up for grabs.

EoS is in the explore and self-direct style of gameplay that was pioneered by Minecraft and Terraria. So if you're familiar with and enjoyed those games, this will be familiar to you but space flavored.

If you've never played such a game, then let me boil it down for you. EoS is an action oriented exploration game where the world is created procedurally (randomly) and you possess no state goals aside from survival. You'll take your trust space pick and mine out a little bit of safety while hoarding resources to use later. Use on what? To craft bigger and more elaborate spacesuits, jetpacks, weaponry and gadgets.

Except, it is beta, so how far that road goes is sort of limited. If you're the type who enjoys seeing games get bigger and more fleshed out then take a chance now and support the devs. Otherwise wait for the full buffet to come out later.

reviewText:
I've played the game off-and-on for the last couple of years, and it is a fun game.  It's Terraria or Starbound, but with better graphics.  However, the content of the game, while not terrible, is still lacking a bit, and there's still a lot of work that needs to be done.  The recent 1.0 Release I feel was a bit premature, as they actually removed some content from the game with the intent of it being added-in later (hopefully not as DLC).

I tenatively rate this with a thumbs-up, but I might change this depending on how it progresses.  I've heard some rumors that some of the planned content for the game will instead be released as DLC, but until that's confirmed I won't downvote it, as I have gotten my money's worth out of the game.

The easy description of this game?  Starbound with better graphics but with less content.

reviewText:
This game is incredible. Why? Here...

Your ship has steered off its path and taken you to a planet that appears to be imploding. You have nothing but standard issue gear ( a mining laser, gun, jetpack and useless armour). You have no choice but to work with your environment to make the planet easier to live on. On your way you encounter space dungeons, strange creatures and even a lot of things that come from terraria!

GRAPHICS-

The graphics of Edge Of Space are sort of simplistic, like those of terraria or minecraft. I normally like simplistic graphics in games but you are forced to look at the same backdrops for AGES which can get annoying. Other than that, I like the graphics.

GAMEPLAY-

Sandbox games are always my favourite types of games as they always have infinite possibilities. No storyline in this game means you are free to do what you want! The sandbox elements (building, breaking and crafting) are excellent in this game. Most sandbox games have a crafting sytem where you need a certain type of item to craft. Edge of Space is all about getting larger amounts of, well, anything! The building and breaking elements are the same as most sandboxes really exept for the fact that you get a huge reach for building, and if your laser is good enough, breaking.

PROBLEMS-

Sadly, I now have to list the few problems this game has...
First! Music.
Music in this game is a small problem. You hear the same backing track over and over again and it gets extremely annoying. It would be better if the backing track for normal days and nights was nice to listen to, like the title screen music, but it's not.
Next! World Gen.
World generation in this game is basically floating islands with dirt, mud and trees. It is literally impssible to find enough USEFUL stuff quickly, without going too far down into the exposure zones. It would be great if there was a small increase in generation of useful things.

Other than that though...
I would toatally recommend this game to any terraria or sandbox fan.


EDIT:

Yay. The Music is better now.


Why does no one like this game?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally Early access done right.

Regular updates, it already got two different huge biomes !
Devs are posting regularly in the steam forums.
This game remembers me of an insane mix of metroid and terraria.
Your an astronaut and embark on a mission to reclaim and terraform a split up planet. The deeper you get the more radiation you will discover so dont forget your protection !
Of course you can setup your outpost and craft all shiny furniture. You can research different armor sets and weapon types like phase and projectile weapons. It got even nice upgrade mechanics like improved health , deploying mini turrets or even a grappling hook !

Now you say what ? Only 2 biomes and terraforming isnt implemented yet ? With terraform i mean turn the land into a more livable space with less radiation and hostile creatures. Base building you can do from the start!
Dont fool yourself the biomes in EOS work much differently than compared to terraria. Terrarias biomes are rather small and can be traversed quickly. But on the other hand EOS's biomes really feel vast and huge. So those areas really invite you to explore and discover new lifeforms and alien buildings :)

Basically the end end goal upon release is to turn the planet back into a livable space with oxygen etc. But terraforming is a future feature.

I think in the past 2 months this early access title did do huge steps in the right direction. I was just on a server now and got disconnected. So i was confused, but actually they pushed an update right now ! So those devs are really crazy with the updates. For example the christmas update included 2 new dungeons , 1 new boss, 1 special event and several new items to craft.


TL;DR
Basically its a blend of 2d metroidvania and terraria. Ranged combat is a huge deal with many rifles and laser guns. Currently you cant do melee combat, which is intended. Each crafted weapon can get different stats and clip sizes etc.

It maybe starts slow and you need to get used to the crafting and research mechanics, but im sure after 4-5 hours you feel right at home :)
But take notice Win Xp is NOT supported !
Mac and linux arent supported yet, but get a future implementation!
Just check out the forums to get a better picture whats going on.
When starting the game first time i strongly recommend doing the tutorial first.



Edit: It got now tons of christmas content. It had so many updates i cant even follow up all ! I think currently it got two different biomes with different flora and fauna and now even a happy new year patch came out!
So obviously still recommended and the updates are amazing :)

reviewText:
Review Updated as of 4/3/2016

How far my hopes have fallen.

This games started out with such great potential. Nice graphics, good crafting and world building mechanics. Even the inclusion of EXP and special in-world events! There were even going to be NPCs. Notice how I say 'were' in that last sentance.

The Developers seem to have left this game behind. In December, they assured us that the next update would come out after they got back from Christmas break, but days turned to weeks, and eventually into months. No update, no word from the Developers, no hope for this game.

The end product is a lot of good ideas that never got to see their full potential. The framework of a great game is there, but now it's never going to be completed.

I had high hopes for this game, and I have no idea with the Devs vanished so suddenly. But despite my dashed hopes, I cannot recoment this game to anyone.

reviewText:
After hours and enduring and trying to play through the horrible UI lag problems I'm still having, I've changed my mind about this game and want to rewrite my review.

First off the UI lag problems shouldn't be something to stop you buying this game as they're not affecting everyone.
I also still feel that a lot of the UIs look messy and unprofessional but that's somthing I'm sure will be updated and improved with time.

Right, ignoring these issues, this game's actually pretty nice. The gameplay is a little limited at the moment but it's still early days. The music is absolutely beautiful, I'm so glad I got the Special Edition so I can listen to this whenever. The number of decorations for your base is incredible, and I really like the art style so you can have a pretty snazzy looking base (unfortunately I'm not very creative so mine isn't). There's a nice bit of comedy in dialogue with the NPCs (although the NPCs seem to know more about me and ArkCo than I do).

All in all, it's not fantastic but give it time because it's still got its potential, just wait for it to shine.

Btw, the dev team are working closely with the community so things WILL actually get fixed and improved.

(If I have to wait five minutes to craft an item again I'm gonna cry, the UI lag is so annoying).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr: Dug up a mushroom, got Uranium; woo! Play this game, it gives Early Access a good reputation.

Every single day, this game becomes more and more appealing to play. balancing, additional content,
The averaging out of the reviews say the general feeling on this game is mixed, but the top reviews are nearly all absolutely positive,
Whereas for Starbound, the general feeling is listed as very positive, but the top reviews are nearly all absolutely negative.
Why?
Because a game that was more polished at release with less attention from the developers (Starbound) is just isn't as good as a less polished game with more developer attention (EoS). This is why Edge of Space is in my favourites and Starbound is not.
Yes, this game DOES need more everything: content, detail, variety, bug fixes, polish, et cetera. But in the same volume, it is RECIEVING what it needs! DEVELOPER ATTENTION!! It warms my heart to see devs responding to reviews and comments and implementing changes based on community feedback~!

There are, however a few small issues I can think of which would address immediate issues.
- Some method of pausing the action
- an option to reverse the scroll for the hotbar
- Beautiful as the background music is, possibly a touch more variety would be welcome
- changing the tiles the master cryopod sits on would be fantastic for base decoration.

On a side note, I purchased the standard version of the game, and then later decided to buy the special edition, but none of the special edition content shows up at all. If it hasn't been implemented properly yet, I'm willing to wait, but I just want to ensure that this isn't simply a bug.

Overall, this game truly lives up to what the developers have claimed, and is improving every day. Keep up the good work devs, you love your game and we love you for it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated review from my last one.

In my previous review I stated how bad this game was and how it seemed to be going nowhere. It felt amateurish and pointless. The tutorial was vague and taught very little.

That was at the beginning of the year and I recently reinstalled the game to see what was new and if things have improved. I'd like to talk about these changes after some brief gameplay:

The first impression that I got was that the tutorial is way better. They aren't always necessary for this kind of game, but before I was baffled on how to build things, now I know. Immediately you are given a gun, fairly weak, but it does the trick, whereas before there seemed no way to kill enemies other than using the mining laser on them or the plasma saw or whatever it was.

So what do I think now? Alot better, my hat is off to you guys for improving upon a royal mess. Not perfect, but still not released. At this rate of improvement I am confident, however, that things will get ironed out.

Some minor problems:

For some reason the install for a game of this type and look is enormous. 1.5 gb download and 3gb disc space. Where it all goes, I'm unsure, but as the art seems to be bitmap and bitmap has large file sizes, I'm inclined to think that it is that.

Screen tearing is quite bad.

Bloody snails pushing me around. Probably by design but annoying.

The worlds seem extremely small. Could perhaps do with you being able to go to other planets or at least make the worlds alot bigger.

Overall, my opinion has swayed. I see potential in this game and I am impressed with the improvements. Keep up the good work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edge of Space is in no way enjoyable in its current state. It is repetitive, bland and pointlessly grindy.

There is no joy of exploration because there is hardly anything to see. 3 Biomes with the same mechanics just reskins and renames of previous resources. And a handful of pre-built dungeons instances that you can travel to, and are awful.

The combat is terrible, there are only 3 weapons that just get reskinned over and over again. And worse, they are so horribly imbalanced that you use the rifle for 95% of combat, the mortar for cheesey splash-damage-through-walls tactics on the other 5% and the carbine is completely pointless as a crappier version of the rifle.

The mechanics are clunky. You can't run down sloped tiles and jump, even though the dungeons are designed with downward sloping jumps in them. Hit detection is dodgey, enemies in certain positions can be invulnerable to direct fire because terrain hit boxes seem to register before enemy ones so your shot somehow ends up blocked by the wall behind them.

The enemies are dull. There's like 16 all told, and half of them are just reskins of the same run-at-player-bump-to-damage design with bigger numbers.

The design is darn well ♥♥♥ backwards sometimes too, for example:

In the dungeon where all your digging and wall placement tools are disabled, the enemies ghost through walls. But out in the sandbox where you can cheese the mechanics, enemies are blocked by walls. Why, in the one place where you can be guaranteed the enemy NPCs can't be path blocked would you put in the world's most annoying terrain ignoring floating enemies?

You have to unlock higher tier crafting by spending experience on generic tech level up consumables and using them, and the amount of unspent experience you can have at any time is capped. So you have to stop every 5 minutes and craft more tech consumables through the laggy crafting menu or start losing out on experience. Why the heck would you try to half-♥♥♥ it through the existing crafting UI rather than give it its own UI to spend experience directly? And even more why the heck would you cap it? Especially cap it so low you have to stop and spend it about 20 times to level up even one tier at later levels.

The whole game is extrodinarily grindy. Everything of value beyond the starter tiers requires converting hundreds of hundreds of junk tiles into a general purpose crafting material (Carbon fibre and super coolant). When enemy specific drops -are- needed, the same enemies drop like 10 different types of item, of which you only need the 1, so you have to farm enemies for 10x longer before you can craft one of anything. And unlocking new crafting tiers takes waaaay longer than it takes to get bored of the last reskin you unlocked hours ago.

And that's why I can't recomend this game even with furter development planned. Hardly any of the updates are exciting or ingenuitive, just more reskins called content. The design choices make no sense. And every system currently in place is poorly implemented. I have not one piece evidence the devs are capable of polish or exciting design in all these gigabytes of early access game.

They can make lots of hi-res sprites though. So there's that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this from kickstarter long time ago, during its ALPHA stages it was great and showed a lot of promise.

They removed most of the enmies for a long time which was kinda frustrating as the game felt like it only had 3 enemis to kill.

They made the world smaller and only go donwards direction which makes it really hard to travel as you cant predict if your jatpack can take it or you die falling.

The quest are a good addition but mostly impossible as with the weapons you can get early they do 1 damage so destroying a craps nest takes so long you cant destroy it before time runs out.
Same thing with defend defence platform, once you take the quest 8 enemies will spawn inside the defence platform and destroy it less than 10 seconds hitting it 15 dam per tick inside the platform.
Also its kinda weird that enmies that hit it are seen in the game wilderness as non damaging mobs and yes they will even hurt you even thou they should not.

The new research system takes far too long to get anything build. Even the basics. As you need to grind load of enemies to get 15-25 points in certain research gategories at random in order to advance it further which requires 1000 or more per level and enemies wont drop reserach date always when killed.

Currently for some reason you cant even build the next weapon in line as its material tables are bugged and it wont allow you to put any of the right materials in to build it.

Also the current weapon system is kinda sad as you can only upgrade your weapon and not really build more weapons jsut the one you have.

Enemies can spawn anewhere, even inside you and they sure like to spawn inside your base all the time. You need to constantly clear it out.

Enemies also tend to have so much hp that with your 1 dam pea shooter you need about 30 shots to kill one enemy and yo ueven have to reaload it slowly. Thou the weapons are made randomly if you are lucky you might get weapon with 2 dam.

The lighting day and night system is getting an upgrade soon which is a great thing but at its current state it is horid. Black boxes that dont even fade in but appear instantly when night comes. Luckily this shoul be fixed soon but its been this bad for a long time.

There are many normal alpha game buggs that dont bother me like animatiosn are the wrong way, characters spazzing out when looking up ( this will be fixed soon too =) ), etc cant craft things, de-sync at servers, etc.

The developers are very active and have improved this game alot thou sometimes things have gone the other way too but currently I dont recomend this. This will prolly be good at some point but not yet. Consider buying terraria, 7 days to die, minecraft or maybe crea while you wait for this to pop up good.

I will edit this review as the game updates, hopefully it get better. I really hope so.

reviewText:
I've played the game off-and-on for the last couple of years, and it is a fun game.  It's Terraria or Starbound, but with better graphics.  However, the content of the game, while not terrible, is still lacking a bit, and there's still a lot of work that needs to be done.  The recent 1.0 Release I feel was a bit premature, as they actually removed some content from the game with the intent of it being added-in later (hopefully not as DLC).

I tenatively rate this with a thumbs-up, but I might change this depending on how it progresses.  I've heard some rumors that some of the planned content for the game will instead be released as DLC, but until that's confirmed I won't downvote it, as I have gotten my money's worth out of the game.

The easy description of this game?  Starbound with better graphics but with less content.

reviewText: CAUTIOUS RECOMMENDATION:\n\nAs of now this game has a solid start. The premise is good and the skill tree is interesting, easy, and fun to make your way through. The game itself is still a bit buggy, with framerate on a singleplayer world as if you were lagging on a multiplayer one. The UI also leaves you wanting something a bit better and easier to use. However, the developers are still putting time into fixing up the game so I am hopeful that issues such as the framerate and UI are addressed. There is also a drastic increase of difficulty as you move deeper into the world, as the enemies become much faster and stronger than you really have any feasible hope to overcome...which means lots and lots of deaths, a minor issue. It just begins to feel grindy and repetitive after the silly penguins and/or bears kill you out of nowhere for the 100th time while you are minding your on business.

reviewText:
This game is incredible. Why? Here...

Your ship has steered off its path and taken you to a planet that appears to be imploding. You have nothing but standard issue gear ( a mining laser, gun, jetpack and useless armour). You have no choice but to work with your environment to make the planet easier to live on. On your way you encounter space dungeons, strange creatures and even a lot of things that come from terraria!

GRAPHICS-

The graphics of Edge Of Space are sort of simplistic, like those of terraria or minecraft. I normally like simplistic graphics in games but you are forced to look at the same backdrops for AGES which can get annoying. Other than that, I like the graphics.

GAMEPLAY-

Sandbox games are always my favourite types of games as they always have infinite possibilities. No storyline in this game means you are free to do what you want! The sandbox elements (building, breaking and crafting) are excellent in this game. Most sandbox games have a crafting sytem where you need a certain type of item to craft. Edge of Space is all about getting larger amounts of, well, anything! The building and breaking elements are the same as most sandboxes really exept for the fact that you get a huge reach for building, and if your laser is good enough, breaking.

PROBLEMS-

Sadly, I now have to list the few problems this game has...
First! Music.
Music in this game is a small problem. You hear the same backing track over and over again and it gets extremely annoying. It would be better if the backing track for normal days and nights was nice to listen to, like the title screen music, but it's not.
Next! World Gen.
World generation in this game is basically floating islands with dirt, mud and trees. It is literally impssible to find enough USEFUL stuff quickly, without going too far down into the exposure zones. It would be great if there was a small increase in generation of useful things.

Other than that though...
I would toatally recommend this game to any terraria or sandbox fan.


EDIT:

Yay. The Music is better now.


Why does no one like this game?

reviewText:
Overall:
I think that in it's current state the game shows a ton of potential and has some very great features. I really like the Terraria/Starbound 2D worldcraft type gameplay and the controls/combat of this particular title does the style justice. If you're a fan of these, this game is a must-play as it is a bit more forgiving than Starbound or Terraria in some ways but also very challenging in it's own right.

Positives:
There is a great amount of appealing content in the game so far. The combat is a lot of fun. I like how easy it is to find and upgrade resources as well as unlocking content by simply fighting monsters and mining. Each (fighting/mining) give you exp points equally. There are also mini-dungeons you come across regularly to clear out. These in addition to deployable tower defense and other styles of mini-game dungeons adds a fun spin to the roguelike worldcraft indie style.

Negative:
The biggest issues I have with the game are stability issues and bugs. After initially binging on the game for several hours, I lost everything I had built due to a client crash. I still had my character and all the inventory, but the planet/area's safe file was corrupted so I had to start from a fresh new save. This made me lose all my storage and the structures/bases I had built.  Also it seems that about half the time the game has trouble deploying your character as playable into the world. Sometimes the screen is dark and everything responds, but you cannot move or take control of your avatar. It is easily fixed by a restart or two (if it happens sequentially).

Neutral:
This game isn't a solid world like in Terraria or Starbound. There are large open spaces inbetween land masses that you must use your jet pack to travel between while heading deeper in the map without taking damage on impact as the gravity is similar to that of earth. This I feel like has both negative and positive effects for creating elevator shafts and fast-travel between different levels. For instance, one thing I liked about terraria was creating an easily navigated mine-shaft to drop very deep very quickly, although in this you can just build a teleporter wherever you want and teleport straight to it. So it really allows you to focus on more combat if you want to.

End thoughts. Worth overall. I will update my review as it is developed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has suffered mass criticism from players, critics and just gernerally people don't like it. I DO NOT see why people hate it...This game is great...Better than Terraria? Nope but still better than other side-scrollers and also you cannot compare it to Teraria as they are pratically two different games.

First off, you create a charater, mine an awesome-looking female with a mask which screams ♥♥♥♥ off to any crab,jellyfish or any 'badguy' that thinks they can take a piece of me.

Then we have the tutorial. I have read reviews where they say that the tutorial didn't help or it didn't give enough depth...well I'm sorry but you must be playing a different game. The tutorial has a video in the bottom right corner of the screen which demostrates how to do stuff and what you needed to do in order to advance through the tutorial. Yes I admit that at times the video played a bit fast so I couldn't keep up with the voice BUT there was text above the video so I didn't even have to worry about it.

Once the tutorial finishes you are thrown straight into the world with little knowledge of what to do next. My thoughts were to build a base...Captain Obvious here...Digging is simple, just like other games, and it wasn't long before I had a decent amount of materials in order to make a base. Now I had two options, Build it in the sky surrounded by jellyfish or on the ground overrun with plants and creepy crawleys. My choice...the sky.

Now I'm not going to run it for you...Try the game you will like it. The ideas that are in this game are truely awesome...There are different guns and ones I would of never thought of such as the Ark Light which shoots torches for quick and easy light...'Oh boy I wish that was in Terraria' was said a few times.

Good side-scroller...Check
Good ideas...Check
Flaws...a few but none ruined the experience
Game of the year...Maybe not but still good
Terraria or Edge of Space...Terraria but I'm am still a devoted fan

This game will grow...New patches often...New features...Yes I've played only an hour or so but my first hour was a good experience so here's to the next 2218947947918 hours of my life :D

reviewText:
8/10

-don't trust the current steam rating, the majority of the negative reviews are 1-2 years old, this game deserves at least a 80% rating. (imho)

-fresh outta EA, this games has a few little bugs here and there, which is only natural. but there's certainly nothing game breaking.

-unlike other devs, you can be sure that these guys will fix bugs within a reasonable time and answer 99% of your questions in the forum.

-similar to terraria and minecraft, this game won't hold your hand: there are some npcs and a in game guide (codex) that give you some hints, but quite a few things you'll have to figure out by yourself, so at least bring a IQ of 80 with you.

-taking terraria as a reference value, EoS does some things better (again, imho):
--> better ambiente: mainly due to the excellent in game music, EoS feels beautifully melancholic and mature without being depressing, it makes you thoughtful. coming back to terraria, you'll figure yourself on a happy LSD trip.
--> better in game music (see above).
--> placing tiles works smooth and easy from the beginning.
--> beautiful art style, and it gets even more beautiful the deeper you go, especially the individual zone backgrounds!
--> devs are 10/10 straight.
--> progression is more versatile: get exp, spend in many different tech trees, find hidden stat upgrades in the world, random stats and bonuses for weapons.
--> you can fly from the getgo with a jetpack, yay! (watch your fuel though!)

Keep in mind: Overall, Terraria in it's current state is better, naturally. Terraria started this whole 2d sandbox genre: Due to a astronomically higher budget and a longer development time, you can't really beat it. If you played Terraria ad nauseam though, if you want to play something similar yet in many ways different, get EoS.
voteText: 10 of 21 people (48%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After going through about 2 hours of this game, I can definitely give this game a recommendation.

Now noted, I played Terraria a few months ago, did some multiplayer with a few friends, and got bored of it. It has been a few months since I last touched it.

Going into this game, I was launched into the tutorial, and got a far better grasp of the basic mechanics than I did when I first got thrown into Terraria. While both do not require special placement for materials and such, this game gave a different emphasis that yes, even dirt is an important resource.

I think that's what really got me into this game. Every resource you mine actually has a use, and you don't have to dump piles of dirt into a chest so it doesn't clutter your inventory. You actually need dirt now.

Another thing that gives this game an edge against other games in this genre is the fact that you get decent ranged weapons through the tutorial. Normally you get a junk sword and all ranged weapons run on limited ammunition. Here, there's infinite ammo and it serves you well enough until you can research better schematics later on. I think that's important.

Finally, I just like the overall look. The background, the creatures, and your character all have a pleasing look that also saves resources so it doesn't eat up the GPU. It has an art style that branches off just enough where it doesn't look too foreign, but still has its own identity.

All in all, good game. If you get it on sale, you got a really good deal.
