reviewText:
This game is ready for primetime and worth the cost, with active developers who have made a fun project.

If you like Terraria, you might like this - it's not as crazy-full of content, but it doesn't have the benefit of time and money that Terraria has had.  It's fun and different enough from Terraria that it presents some unique value.

There are a couple cons: balancing and game progression.  You get relatively little guidance in the overall 'purpose' of the game - what you're trying to accomplish, all the features, crafting progression, etc.  This can be annoying, especially absent a robust wiki which Terraria possesses.  Moreover, the damage done by enemies is all over the scale, and it's hard to predict how a particular tier of armor will prepare you for the next group of baddies.  Right now it feels like enemies can swarm very quickly and do crazy amounts of damage quickly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm giving this game a recomend.
Keep an eye on this game. I enjoy it, and I believe it will be a really good game when it's finished.
I don't usually write reviews for early access games, but I'm giving this a positive because it has so many unjust downvotes from people who didn't give the game a chance. I believe the review system as-is doesn't quite work for early access games and needs a redesign that would be more fair to the product and it's changes over time (or lack there-of) and the reviewers who give their opinion.

The biggest positives of this game:
If it has a bug, the devs will fix it as quickly as possible.
They update the game regularly.
The devs really listen to the feedback, and replies from the community managers and devs themselves are often.
I enjoy the game and the gameplay. This one is last because it's an early access game that is unfinished and somewhat unpolished, but I'm positive this game will keep getting better and better (as it already has been), and it will actually reach a 1.0 version and players will be happy with it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSince I first started playing EOS I have noticed a ton of improvement. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is based on the December 2014 version of the game.  As it currently stands, it holds alot of promise, but suffers from usability problems.  For example. there is nothing you can do with your old gear - when you make new equipment, you can't salvage or sell your old items that are no longer useful, you have to delete them (or store them if you're a pack rat).  Also, the UI is still pretty rough - some recipe names don't match up to what they create.  This is a problem when you are trying to figure out where the 'crafting bench 1' recipe is, because its actually the 'computerized work bench' recipe.

Overall its decently fun, but the clunkiness of the UI drove me to give up on figuring out what I needed to do next.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Professional Preview (Italian): http://www.everyeye.it/pc/articoli/edge-of-space_provato_24950

Abstract translated in English:
Edge of Space is a promising heir to the 2D sanbox legacy initiated by Terraria, which introduces deep changes in one of the fundamentals of the genre: the crafting system. Having to invest your hard earned experience points in developing every single Research branch to discover their advanced recipes is both an incentive to explore the world in solo play and specialize your character in multiplayer games. There are bugs here and there, but the developers are actively supporting the game through continous patch deploying. We can't wait to see what new features will be introduced in the next updates: we'd like to see a compass that aims to your last bound cryopod or a geological probe to see what resources can be found in the area.

Commento in Italiano:
Edge of Space è un promettente erede della tradizione sandbox bidimensionale iniziata da Terraria, che introduce novità incisive in una delle meccaniche principali del genere, il crafting. La necessità di sviluppare i singoli campi di ricerca, investendo i punti esperienza ottenuti interagendo con l’ambiente, per scoprire le ricette più avanzate, aggiunge un incentivo a procedere nelle partite in solitaria e, allo stesso tempo, permette una maggiore personalizzazione dell’esperienza di gioco in multiplayer. I bug non mancano, ma le continue patch pubblicate dallo sviluppatore mitigano in parte la situazione, oltre a introdurre nuovi elementi di gameplay. Non ci resta che vedere quali altre feature verranno introdotte nei prossimi aggiornamenti: magari una bussola che punti verso la propria criocapsula o una sonda geologica per mappare le risorse presenti nell’area circostante.

reviewText: I enjoyed the game. It has a nice mix of Terraria-style exploring and base building and fast-paced Metroid-style shooting. It has vehicles, a decent progression system, quests and NPCs.\n\nSure, it has some downsides (most annoyingly UI lag) and parts of the game feel unfinished (vehicles IMO could be much more useful than they currently are). But overall I found the game reasonably enjoyable and don't quite get all the negativity (I think it's more of a case of unmet expectations than the game being objectively bad).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked up Edge of Space on Desura when it first released, played about 20 minutes and thought WTF DID I JUST WASTE MY MONEY ON. I guess I knew it was early access but... at that point it was REALLY early access. It was the skeletal framework of the game and nothing else.

Fast forward to my picking it up on steam, and the game is completely different, more fleshed out and with its own unique personality. It's still very clearly not done yet. But the parts of this genre that make it fun to play, mining, gear and stat upgrading, and base building, are functional and enjoyable. It sounds like the developers have a clear vision in mind for what the game will be, and as it progresses in development that vision becomes more and more clear each patch both in the game's functionality and tone.

TL;DR - It's early access done right. Game has regular updates and gets fleshed out more and more with each one. It's also fun to play in its current state of development.

I love this genre of game and yes there are others like it but edge of space has way tighter graphics. i am getting a little tired of the pixel look. i liked it for a while but now it seems lazy. Edge of space has regular updates, check the log. i have been burned on early access but with regular updates i feel like there is an end in sight. starbound has been early access for two years does not have the reguar updates this one has and is not done yet. btw i also own starbound, the only reason i mention it is the obvious comparison. my time playing is not fully represented by the amount shown. Game is creative , clever and nearly infinite in scope due to the sand box nature and mods.

i also own terraria, craft the world, king arthur's gold and dig or die, as i said i like the longevity of this type of game. edge isn't up to craft the world or terreria yet but it is still young and terraria was made in 2011. so it has time to play catch up for a truly fair comparison.

the best thing i can say about it is i had a free review copy but bought it anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, this game is amazing even though I haven't played it recently so I don't understand why there are bad reviews. I hardly ever write a review but I felt this game is worth my time reviewing. With all the new updates, I am actually going to set out some free time to play it again. In fact, I enjoyed this game even before all the big updates and patches were made (wipes included).


It is similar to Terraria in the aspect of genre but uniquely different in terms of content.

Edge of Space speaks for itself what it's about (almost). You are an alien thrown into an unknown world". Whether it was a planet or on an asteroid
date: even I'm not quite sure. Everyone complains it's hard to grasp but there is a tutorial at the beginning which I happened to accidentally skipped. Even so
recommended: I didn't find the game entirely hard to follow if you know the basics: collect materials
hoursPlayed: build a house/base
voteText: kill monsters
helpfulPercent: etc. Not to mention all the cool pets and mounts you can create. Come on...a laser to collect materials and space guns?! Jet packs to fly! It really sticks to the sci-fi feel. Oh
votesHelpful:
I would also like to add I love how smooth the movements are in this game.

The challenge is in figuring how everything works and the satisfaction when you do.

Since last time that I played
votesTotal: the only thing I really would complain about is how each character was bounded to certain worlds if they were made in multiplayer/single player. You can't select any character to load into a world if that character wasn't made in that particular world. Some materials that can be collected in single player were unable to be gathered in multiplayer (but before I stopped playing this issue was already fixed). There weren't as many boss fights as I would like and their drops weren't always anything special. Overall
votesFunny: when I stopped playing I was merely waiting for more content to be released.\n\nI've seen a lot of reviews comparing this to Terraria and Starbound. If you like those games more then play those games instead of comparing it to this one. Why? Because if this game was exactly like Terraria then...that defeats the purpose of making a uniquely different 2D Sandbox game. Also
commentsCount: if you hop into the game for less than an hour and deem that it's awful then you're not even giving the game a chance.\n\nI would also like to repeat that this game is in EARLY ACCESS. There will be bugs and the sort so if you don't want a game that's in DEVELOPMENT
column16: I would advise you to wait if you have no patience for an unfinished game rather than buy it and give it a bad review because it has a lot of potential."

updated the thread (up to date as of March 04 2016 1.09 holiday update)

The comparisonterraria and edge of space and very disimilar games

both are 2d exploration hack and slash shoot em ups with flight aspects,
both have dungeons with bosses
both have biomes with biome specific mobs
both have accessories (kits = accessories)
both have vanity
both have ranged, flying, and melee mobs
both have bosses, one of them is a near straight rip from terraria (crossover, rip, close enough)
both have at some point been seemingly abandoned
one makes huge updates rarely, the other makes small updates rarely
both have pets, and minions
both have grapples
both have mounts
both are falsely claimed to be survival" games
both have classes
both have world and character saves seperate
both are procedually genrated
neither have huge true variety in world gen
both have structures"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer:  This is an early access title, so as always, buyer beware.  It may or may not make it to the finish line, but from what I've experienced over a few years development cycle with this game, it's team is nothing if not dedicated and focused on the goal of pushing this game to release, so I'm fairly confident it will be released, just not as hastily as other titles.

The question to be answered, is whether or not this game is worth buying right now.  While it's in the same sandbox genre as popular (and depending on who you ask, infamous) titles such as terraria, minecraft, and starbound, the graphical style sets it apart fairly decisively.  It's not super high-res, but the cartoonish yet realistically proportioned characters are a nice change from the pixelized Devs-Don't-Give-A-Damn you sometimes see.  What can I say, some people like pixels, others don't.  For my part, I do like pixels.  Anyway, see the screenshots for a good idea of the art style.  At the very least, the art style is consistent throughout the game as far as I've seen.

The devs have taken an interesting direction in the way of progression, in that every action you take, whether it be killing monsters, felling alien vegetation, or just digging up some mud, nets you experience that can be spent toward research in the area of your interest.  It's an interesting component that I suppose promotes cooperation and teaming up with other players who can fill the gaps in your research to help fully kit out your base.  Materials aren't enough to build all that you need, you actually need the experience and research level to create equipment and objects, unlike terraria and starbound where you only need touch a component to know how to put it together.

The alien environments don't take the typical planetoidal approach to world generation, and instead you find your avatar cast adrift on a sea of floating islands, which you can hop from one to the next with a handy jetpack, which you get from playing through the tutorial at the very beginning of the game.  It's necessary to build a suit of armor with exposure protection in order to delve deeper into the world's depths, so progression is a multi-pronged challenge as you have to gather experience and then spend it correctly in order to build a base and equip yourself for the dangers you'll find in the lower levels of the planet.

There's not much else for me to say about this title, but if you're still on the fence after hearing all of this, know that the game is still in development, and in order to expedite the process your characters and worlds may be wiped.  So bear that in mind if it's a factor in your decision.

For my part, I bought it at 20 dollars a while back, and like where the game is going.  I trust this dev team enough to get the job done eventually, and really look forward to when it's finished.  If you have the money to spare and want to put it to a project, and this one sounds good based on all you've heard, great.  Honestly, this either is your cup of tea or isn't, and that's okay.  I will say that it's my cup of tea, and an interesting and very different entrant to the 2d sandbox genre.  I don't regret buying the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, I am enjoying the game immensely. Although all the buildings I have discovered have been empty, I remind myself its EA and the content will come.
The game so far has many features I love, that other sandbox games I have played are lacking; I love the crafting and research, the points system to unlock new tech, I love the companions and the mounts. Edge Of Space has dragged me away from the other sandbox games I am playing, and I can't wait for it to be finished so that all the content is in place. Do yourself a favour, if you buy one sandbox game this week, but Edge Of Space.

The one area however, where this game stands out against all others, is the extraordinarily first class interactions from the devs; I have never come across devs who are so quick to answer questions from the community, actively seek feedback and entrench themselves amongst the fans, and keep them informed constantly and consistently. This alone would make for a first class title, but factoring in all the other features, many of which. I haven't even mentioned, should,  I hope, make EoS a cult classic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are many reviews that go ionto specifics about the pros and cons of this game, so mine is going to be short and sweet:

As it stands, it is not worht the $12.99 I paid. I really want to like it, but it is clumsy, aimless, and unnecessarily challenging. A poor user interface only makes it more glaringly obvious that similar games are better. The art style for the characters is a nice touch, but the textures for the more common things like dirt and mud are ugly at best. The music needs work and there are some game-ending glitches.

Wait to purchase this one until it has some polish. I wish I could say more polish" but it feels like they haven't even started yet. I'll be going back to Starbound for the time being."

reviewText: So I got this back in its EA days and thought it had promise. I thought it would be a nice game to take the place of Terraria. The game never got very good or polished and then the Devs decided to call it finished and released it. Well you can call it what you want, I guess, but finished is certainly not how I would describe this game. If you don't have Terraria, play that instead. If you've burnt out on Terraria and are looking for a replacement- run. Run as fast as you can as far as you can.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like Terraria, then yes this is a game to get.
True, it is in the early developmental stage and there are a plethora of bugs, incomplete items, and overall balancing issues that still need to be worked out.
For a game still well into its beta, i find it damn impressive that it wants me to keep playing as much as it does.
Gameplay is not as smooth as i would prefer, e.g. no invinicibility frames upon taking damage, enemies ridiculously hard to hit with guns, having a ceiling on the max amount of ammo you're allowed to have for everything besides phase weapons. In all honesty, I felt that Terraria handled the ammo situation for projectile weapons very well, where you could have as much as you wanted as long as you had inventory space. Reloading of course is something they didn't incorporate but the upper limit on ammo makes projectile weapons nearly obsolete. Haven't tried energy weapons yet, hope they are better, otherwise its sticking to phase weapons forever just because of ammo constraints.
Mining can be tedious, as i have not found any new ores or reasons to mine besides the fact i need resources to farm xp from the enemies flying around, and your upgraded picks dont seem to be digging that much faster.
Dungeons on here are very exciting to explore, i was amazed when i first discovered the headhunters dungeon, and again when i found maps to other dungeons as you went lower.
Transportation mounts, like the raptors, can't teleport with you to different command nodes, which i found to make them  not very useful since you get to them so much later in the game and need to move around between your main base and hub bases quickly.
random events that happen are interesting, they are usually pretty tough, although the rewards are severly lacking. Kill x/x monsters and you get a couple blocks of some ore thats not very rare? not worth it.
also can we get a map early on? exploring's a ♥♥♥♥♥ without one, even if we have to make it but make it available from a fairly early point please.
I am very excited to see this game get completed, hope that this review persuades others to invest in this game and help support the developers.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTerraria was a major sucess, but it looks like the developers thought it wasn't enough. Edge of Space is a great game. I can tell that even though I've only played for less than an hour, it has a lot of potential. If you think of it like this, Terraria is the older kind brother, and Edge of Space is the little brother seeking to follow in Terraria's foot steps to sucess. And if your on the fence on if you want to get it or not, i suggest you get the game and get to watch this game bloom into a sucess like terraria did.

reviewText: well i hate to say it but this is just a mess multiplayer is non-existant as it currently fails to load most of the time. charecters are restricted to per instance/world loading (you cant have charecters in multiplayer on both you and someone elses world.) the game is very laggy often crashes even in single player. the multiplayer uses a vulnerable port that often cannot be opened/hosted while an antivirus is running or a firewall is active. finaly multiplayer isnt easy to setup as you need to know how to forward ports find your ip and other technical knowledge that most players like me lack completeley.\nthe singleplayer lacks a story and most of all is very repetative each 3 layers adds 2 new ores.... wow.... it takes hours to actualy find most of these ores in a descent quantity and often the mobs kill you before you can mine it. talking of mobs they seem to spawn everywhere especialy in the 3rd 6th and 9th islands the 6th island is inacessable to players without armor found 3 layers deeper (that you then wouldent be able to craft) the games drop rates need a massive boost as they currently are taking the p~~~. the bosses" in the game lack any difficulty whatsoever and additionaly drop next to nothing for your time especialy the dj penguin whose armor set may need 30~40 kills to aquire and 21 hours of my gameplay was wasted making it. the game`s mobs are no better the egnoid matiriels take hours to find also the mobs that drop them dont seem to spawn as often making it very hard to get anywhere endgame the dungeons are nice but dont have any reward execpt 1 mob worth of science xp (not worth it) the ambient mobs eat viechles so it isnt worth crafting them especialy as they are single use finaly the singleplayer lacks a map and this isnt acceptable the maps is needed for the game to be minorly enjoyable as of now players just get lost in the middle of nowhere."

The game is playable but unfinished. The game starts with this vague tutorial. Ofcouse, tutorials are there to help you in-game but this tutorial is kind of weird. A tutorial should show what is really good in a game. But instead of giving that to you, they give you this level of an depressive room I guess.The game plays laggy and unsmooth. It feels just like a flash game. Seriously. In the trailer you see smooth NPC's/Players, but when I bought the game and started it, it wasn't that at all. I bought the game to quick. I'm a really big fan of Terarria and when I saw this, I was completely sold. But I felt betrayed when I played the tutorial. Yes, it is an Early Access Game. But do not buy this because you thought the trailer looked ''cool'' or whatever . (Me) But I do see alot of potential in this game and I hope that the developers make a great game of it. And that is because I DO RECOMMEND this game. Developers , please make a good game of this.

- Booker

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dont get this game, get starbound instead. Even if this is in early access, it still has barely any content that is worth mentioning because of it's lack of originality. If you do actually enjoy the game, i would wait until its finished and not waste your money now seeing as how the developer doesnt frequently update the game at all.

*EDIT*

Gameplay-wise:
The UI and the crafting are terrible / counter-inutitive, inventory management and combat is sub par, and the atmosphere is just boring and lackluster. Music is either just ambience or just music that feels like it is someone's first time with FL studio.  There are the usually bugs gliches here and there but that is subjected to change since it is in beta.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFun if you like buggy Beta games. For a 3 month period or so, i couldn't even load the game without it CTD! The dev's fixed that, but it's still a long march to the finish it seems. Oh hey guys, Terreria content! C'mon, get some original ideas for Christ's sake! Pixelated avatars and a big skull boss do not make me want to re-install. Cool original content, maybe, but not re-hashed ideas borrowed from another game, pshhh! ******MMORPG.com - Best Indie RPG at PAX East 2014****** <--- this bothers me, because it's NOT an RPG, and it's being rated by an MMORPG report, which furthers my distain. Firstly, it's a sandbox crafting game, with zero RPG elements. Sorry, but being in control of an avatar does not constitute, otherwise EVERY game would be an RPG. And just because you can augment items does NOT mean it's an RPG, nor is that even an element. That being said, NOT AN RPG, and it's certainly not the best, and I'm sure there were dozens at PAXE2014 lol. In order for it to be a Role Playing Game, there needs to be an implemented stroy line with varried choices offered to allow alternate paths of progression.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edge of Space is a game still in development. There will, of course, still be bugs and pending/missing features. However, at this stage, it is still a pretty fun game to play. I'm still relatively early in the game, but I still got plenty of stuff to do and to look forward too.

However, and I will say it again, IT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT.
At this stage, not many people may like it as it is. The developers are still working on getting a lot of things in the game. They have lots of features planned to be implemented which are currently not present at the moment. The game is not done and there is still a lot to add.

Another thing: Stop comparing it to Starbound. Just because it's a randomly generated, 2D scrolling, sci-fi themed, mining, crafting, and building based game; it doesn't mean it's a clone of that game. It has many different mechanics and the devs took a different approach to the genre. Don't compare the two.

My final note is this: If you want a fun terraria-like space game, you can go with either Starbound, Signs of life, or this game, Edge of space. Whichever you choose, don't compare it with/to the others two. I've only played Edge of Space, and I've loved it.
However, if you don't like to playing unfinished games, I recommend you not to buy it; or at least not right now. It's up to each one's preferences.

8/10:Can't wait for each update.

reviewText: Edge of Space is very addicting...just like any other Gathering / Building game! You can very easily find yourself losing track of time as you dig a hole on a quest for that elusive material that you need for your next craft. Really enjoyed the music and the colourful settings! The crafting can seem overwhelming, but once you get the hang of it...it's really easy! Only wish there was a fullscreen or windowed fullscreen mode (maybe there is, but i couldn't find). This game would be fun to play with friends, as you can become a fighter, builder or gatherer...so there'd be some nice synergy with a few others! Pick this game up!

reviewText:
First review:

Played 15 minutes and had enough.
More a chore than a game. Graphics are poor and over saturated, gameplay is clunky and the inventory system is a pile of s♥♥♥.

Second review:

After my first review the developer sent me a message asking what I didn't like and saying that maybe I haven’t played enough to like it. Well guess what… I played it again (another 15 minutes).

The game should be enough and shouldn’t be so needy to rely in the codex. Is a real pain to read that much instructions for something so simple… find stuff then build stuff.

The game is derivative, is like the Frankenstein of games but in a bad way. The graphics are just wrong… “Hey lets draw one sprite that make no sense and is not iconic and multiply it all across the screen, no matter if nobody understands what that is.”

Very poor move making enemies harder just because you go deeper... lack of imagination.

On the bright side it has a lot of funny bugs like the moonwalking and how the whole screen trembles whenever you try to pass through a gap in a wall.

By the way the collision system is a complete mess, it reminds me the game CheetahMen form Action 52’s for NES.

For those who don’t know what CheetahMen is (or what NES is…) here it is:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tD6wAjpPbro
voteText: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Edge of Space is a Terraria but sci-fi effort in the same vein as the more popular Starbound, even going as far as to include Terraria crossover content, which was one of the selling points of the game for me. It is also one of the most tedious and uninteresting games I've ever played. The basic gameplay loops are completely uninspired and dull. Terraria has wonderfully satisfying Metroidvania progression that makes slowly mining the world in order to acquire better gear and be able to defeat more difficult enemies an absolute joy to play. In the strictest sense, it's a very repetitive game, but it all feels so good that it's wonderfully engrossing. Edge of Space achieves none of that. It's a grind that just feels like a grind, and even in 1.0 is still a bit toward the wonky side, particularly the jumping mechanics.\n\nI have issues with Starbound and it also misses some of what made Terraria work, but it at least feels like there's potential there, and even still in beta it is a lot more fun than this. Edge of Space needs fundamental design overhaul and the 1.0 release really is just polishing a game that never actually worked on the most basic level. One thing I can say for it is that I don't think the graphics are as bad as some other people are making them out to be. Don't get me wrong, they're certainly not great, but I don't think they're intolerable. In a very fun game, they'd probably be fine. Unfortunately this is not a game that plays well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is utter ♥♥♥♥. The crafting is clunky and nonsensical, making machine rifles out of dirt and mud and other things. It is also clear that it's aping Starbound's layout but being even more irritating and difficult to use, needing to push the craft button multiple times in a specific place for it to even work. the worlds are impossible to navigate without dying from a massive fall, there is almost no character customization unless you count the person's face. And just their face.

Just get starbound. This game is fugly and the enemies are nearly impossible to fight due to them being tiny and do half of your health bar's worth of damage on a hit, and utter lack of melee weapons.

Now for me, the aesthetic is garbage except for maybe the backgrounds and sky of the game. It's like one of those minecraft knockoffs with 'HD' textures that look like garbage and not because of the fact it's a voxel-based sandbox world building game.

Do not get this game if you are thinking of getting it over starbound.

reviewText:
I got this, I think, as a part of a promotion ages ago for buying Terraria? Back when it was in open beta if I remember right.

The game, now that I've bothered to redownload it, still feels like it's in an open beta, which is disheartening. There's a lot of stuff that the game doesn't tell you easily, like about upgrades, progression, zones, etc. Granted this also happens with other similar games (including Terraria), but they don't feel like you're being thrown to the wolves. It took me most of one play session to figure out how to pick up items after you put them down, because the game doesn't explain it well and most online sources don't explain it well either. It just doesn't feel like you're doing much other than occasionally jumping off ledges and falling to your death. It's written well, like the flavor text is entertaining pmuch all of the time, but I'm not playing for flavor text, I'm playing for the game.

Guns and jetpacks from the start are fun but I don't know much of what to do and the game feels really glitchy for a full release, so I wouldn't really recommend this myself.

reviewText:
I first found this game a few versions ago and was a bit unimpressed...
You needed to be a programmer to figure anything out, there was no direction or indication of what half of everything was and most of the game's features seemed to be 'almost useful'.

I am glad to say that game is no more and this one now stands on it's own and holds weight!
Sure, it's still early days and some things need tweaking, adding to, explaining etc... but this game has come so far in such a short time that it's gone from 'complicated mess' to 'diamond in the rough'.

I enjoy playing this and will add to this review as the game improves.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are some things wrong with the game right now, but they still have time to change it before the full release. I feel that the tutorial is a bit lengthy (maybe just because of the reading). There are things called crab nests that spawn crabs and both have way too much health because they can spawn in close to when you start the game.

The game is not as polished as Terraria and it's not as good as Terraria. There is not that much guidance after the tutorial and it just seems that the game wasn't ready to be in an early access stage. There are very apparent things that are wrong with the game and their internal testing (if they even did any) should have picked up on it.

Overall, the game seems pretty fun and I trust the creators to make this a really good game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I went into Edge of Space, hoping for something of a cross between Terraria and Starbound. Unfortunately, it did not deliver.

Firstly, there are several menus. too many menus, assigned to keys that you could possibly change, but why? why are there so many?
Navigating story text is also a pain, and the tutorial is horrible. it conveys the controls, but the way it does it is more of a chore it has to do, ticking off parts of the game on a checklist. You don't feel like you've learned anything.

Then there is death. this is perhaps my biggest axe to grind. it turns death into some complex process involving crafting a chamber, and using rods, and I just give up at that point.
I spawned in, tried to slowly edge down from the top of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ asteroid field it dump-ed me into really? couldn't have started with rolling hills? something normal??) and died. I had no idea what to do or how to do it.


Edge of Space is a game full of potential. however, it is far, far too complicated. it has a LOT of work to do to get the gameplay user-friendly, and the death mechanic needs some serious reworking.

It feels like this game is trying to be terraria 2.0, while also trying to be starbound, but not grasping what makes starbound fun. It takes the sci-fi all right, but it takes the grungy abandoned-spaceship theme. Not the adventuring and simplistic controls.

Sadly, I cannot recommend this game for a variety of reasons:

1) the GUI is quite clunky, and not intuitive.

I know this game is really early development, but come on! At least have some generic description of the items or dialogue! Not Insert Description Here"...

I think the problem with this game is that it has POTENTIAL

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had fun with this game ever since it first started on early access, but especially with the latest updates it's really gotten a lot funner and more polished all around. Watching the developer streams has made me pretty excited for the coming updates, with a player-drawable map and a bunch more NPCs and content coming.

I also really love the atmosphere and presentation in this game, and while it still has quite a bit to come before a full release, I think it's definitely worth trying if you like what you see.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is probably one of the best games I've ever played. It is filled with content from start to finish, never once have I encountered a single bug.

Did the developers forget to remove the early access tag? With how developed it is, it shouldn't be early access.

I mean seriously one of the best well put together games, and its replayability? Unlimited.....simply unlimited.

Terraria / Starbound can simply NOT compare to a masterpiece that is this game.

This game makes Terraria look like an early access piece of junk. Same with Starbound.

The tutorial explains everything so well, definitely the best tutorial I've ever seen in a video game before. The tutorial alone is worth playing the 13$ for, a lot of fun to be had. And it explains everything so well, with ZERO bugs.

Oh also, the combat? It is simply spectacular, tremendous, this game makes GTA 5, Mad Max, Metal Gear Solid all look like pieces of junk (compared to this game), hell any does not stand to the greatness that is Edge of Space. If I could give this game to everybody, I would, everybody deserves to play this masterpiece of a game.

reviewText:
I understand I only spent a few minutes in this game, but unfortunately that was all I needed.

First problem I encountered that immediately threw me into a rage...audio crackling.

Normally I would believe this to be some sort of sound driver issue, but as someone who regularly uses Skype, Pandora, numerous other games and software with absolutely zero problem in sound, I found this to be the foreshadowing of the only stain in my library out of (currently) 147 other items. Reinstallation of drivers and the game itself has produced no fix. Fabulous.

Second issue, which I should say was already mentioned by someone else in the reviews on this item...sluggish gameplay. It feels like you're trying to swim through molasses. I was trying to gun down uh, floating jellyfish and other unpleasant critters and it felt like I was in a slow-motion Matrix scene (minus the badassery by a long shot, that is).

Third issue. There were no prominent enough sound effects for mining or busting something's skull in. I expected some splattering or crumbling or something. What I got was a ♥♥♥♥-poor puff noise for most of it. Seriously? What kind of horse crap is this?

Fourth issue. I'm very happy I was able to adapt to the game itself as quickly as I did, because the game not pausing with the tutorial UI up in my face was extremely unsettling and left me open to get owned by the nearest hungry maw. Someone with very little experience with games like this will not be so fortunate in the future.

Fifth issue. This game  has some sloppy sprite work on the player avatars. Normally I would let this slide, but I know this game has been worked on for quite some time, so no, I am not going to let it go. Hell no. You can definitely tell a lot of the features you're able to add onto the avatar in creation were lazily pasted on. Thankfully, the fitting futuristic artwork helped balance it out.

Sixth issue. OH HOW CUTE THE GAME ONLY HAS A RESOLUTION CHANGE OPTION AND V-SYNC FOR GRAPHIC SELECTIONS. LOL WTF IS THIS, 2004?!

Edge of Space was supposed to be the answer to the demand of an outer space sandbox game like Terraria. In fact, when it was advertised, it was proclaiming to be better and a bit of a sequel to the installment. What a waste of cyberspace and time! Terraria is everything this game wanted to try to be. You know, functional and good?

In fact, if you want a good sandbox game similar to Terraria that occurs in space, either sit down with Minecraft and some mods, or get a game that actually does this ♥♥♥♥ right; STARBOUND.

Save your money, ladies and gents. This title belongs in the dev studio for quite a few years more before it should touch the stores.

I can't believe my friend wasted his money to get this for me. I want to actually pay him twice the amount of what he spent on this game just to compensate for the disgrace I went through in giving this a chance.

reviewText:
So the crap hit the fan. Game is 1.0.
So far:
-You can't create new avatar or world at 800x600 resolution, cause buttons are cut out.
-To change resolution you must restart the game.
-World generation takes ages. 15 minutes later world still generating...
-After  killing the game with task manager and running it again world finally loaded
-If you want to play windowed 800x600 GUI elements and quest goals will cover most of your screen and half of your active bar wont be visible

When you place a torch on a block that block is indestructable. For real, if there is a teleporter just make a base walls covered with torches and its eternal.
Looks a little better than in beta, but still design is archaic.
I wont even bother to play any further as basic mechanics of building make this horrible, torch is standing on this block so even nuclear explosion wont destroy it.

I must add that vechicles simply vanish when they get out of fuel...
No words for this failed game, and no hope.

Not worth the time and money at all.
Stay away at all cost.

reviewText:
Basically, if someone saw the concept art for starbound and tried to make a clone of that but for the Sega Genesis...

I bought this game AGES ago, but because of the negative reviews, I thought I'd wait till the 1.0 launch to give it a propper chance.  It feels very much unfinished, and there is no real goal to the game.  Progress feels very slow and grindy
(e.g. an upgraded version of something takes lots of resources, but then is not noticably better)

Graphics 3/10
Gameplay 3/10

I think many aspects of this game may have seemed like a good idea in isolation, but unfortunatly it just hasnt come together well.  I dont think this game can be improved much though, because many of the problems are fundamental game-design issues.

I imagine people who would like this game would also like Starbound.  Anyone who has played Starbound will see how heavily EOS has borrowed from it.  I have problems with starbound too (slow development, bad community management, broken promises). That said Starbound is a much more polished game than EOS, and has much more game play (from what I have seen so far).
even its its slow, poor development never reaching the and of beta state.

I really wanted to like this game... but I just can't do it, after 2.6 hours of REALLY trying to.  The game play is responsive enough, and I have found only a few bugs.  I would suggest watching a gameplay video before buying though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I tried this game, i really did.
I bought this game because of the crossover event it had done with terraria and terraria is one of my favourite games, and the trailers and screenshots looked cool.
However, once i had bought it it took about a few minutes to install but once i had started it up it took about 15 minutes just to load the intro level. Once i had actually started my own world i almost instantly found myself falling from a floating island into a pitch-black hole with no source of light except my mining tool's laser pointer which was next to useless. I looked around for possible solutions to this on the internet (getting out of the hole, being able to see more than 5 pixels of my surroundings at a time, etc.) but i couldn't find any good sites that really gave me a good solution.
If you have bought this and expect it to be as good as terraria, please just don't waste your time on this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not sure yet.

For an early access game it certainly shows some potential, but there are a few things that really bring it down for me.

Pros:

- I like the art style, characters/enemies/backgrounds all look nice.
- Some character customization is nice.
- Space age laser pick axe type thing with rifles to defend yourself is always promising.
- Has a decent tutorial that I would have probably been 100% lost without.
- I liked the quest/task system in place that was used for the tutorial. I would love to see this used a good bit in later builds of the game. Random quests/tasks/challenges while exploring the world would add a good bit of excitement for me.


Cons + personal opinions/feedback:

- The UI. Oh man the UI. This is the one thing that, if not updated significantly, will stop me from playing this game again. Every time I'd look for something I felt myself straining my eyes trying to discern exactly what I was looking at. Similar looking icons in inventory, small text in several places, and a very clunky and unrefined crafting menu (in a crafting game) made it so that every time I'd stop blasting things with my laser saw to go look at my loot or craft something I would grumble to myself a little bit about how I had to go back into the menus. I hope updates are coming for some of UI/menus, especially the crafting menu and/or system. Please oh please.

- Also didn't care for the health/jetpack meters being on such a noisy panel up in the corner like they are. It was a hassle to try and read while running/fighting anything. I would rather just have a couple of bars or numbers above my character or some such thing so that I can see a gauge while I am looking at my character and moving about.

- The [lack of] transition from day to night was so abrupt that I thought it was a bug or my game was crashing or textures had stopped drawing. Day/night is great to have, but needs to be a transition, not instant.

- It seems like the way to unlock new things to craft is by collecting these little book things that give +25 or so to various crafting skills. I don't much care for that as a gating mechanic, maybe it would be better if more was available initially or if there was a better indication of how using different materials to craft the same item would make a better one. Additionally, I really didn't enjoy that I would find these little books, then have to go into my inventory, select them, equip them on my action bar, and then pull them out and use them in order to gain experience from them. Unless they are to be used for something else I am unaware of, I don't understand why they are inventory items instead of just experience type pickups that occur automatically and scroll a nice little +25 Furniture!" or something over your head.

I should stop rambling. There's my 2 cents.

I hope some of this has been helpful if anyone's read this far. I know people compare this game to Terraria
date: which I have not played. It may very well be that much of what I don't like is based around Terraria's success and these elements I don't like just aren't to my tastes. If that's the case then I guess it just isn't for me - ignore all that junk above. :)\n\nMy conclusion - As it exists now
recommended: several different issues come together to make a disappointing experience. I hope that is just due to it being in an early stage
hoursPlayed: and that we'll see much more polish/improvement in the next few months. I think that when/if the right things are made better the whole game could come together quite nicely.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Three words: Hire an Artist

This game just looks bad. From horrible character design to tile graphics that are actually painful to look at, this game is in desperate need or proper art design.  Everything is muddy, hard to look at, of disjointed styles, and just plain ugly, overlayed by one of the worst looking and most unintuative UIs conceivable.

Besides it's horrid appearance, and despite some interesting ideas in crafting and cunstruction, the gameplay is just frustratigly unfun. Talk of features like terraforming and such drew me in when I originally purchased this on Desura long before it's Steam release, but if these features are implemented, I have never gotten to a point in the game where I could see them,  Instead, I have been confronted with a constant, and often fruitless hunt for materials to construct devices that ever seem to opperate as expected.

Frustration always takes me over, and I quit in disinterest.  Not a great entry to the Scifi crafting genre.

Early Access Review

I would like to take this opportunity to call this game silly and bad. Terraria is better, cheaper, and the people who make it are nicer, so go get that instead.

This is just not a good game, and to this day remains the one item of my library that I truly regret adding. With all others, I was intelligent about the purchase, and bought them only after careful research, playing of demos, reading of reviews etc. (or getting them in a bundle, of course)

I learned these habits from my run-in with this game. I guess you should get it if you're constantly giving in to impulse buys, so that you may learn the ways of the Steam Ninja Lords.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is marketed like as a clone of Tererria. This is only partially true. I really like Tererria, but I don't like this game. I understand that this game is still in early development, but based on what I have seen so far it is headed down the wrong path.

1. Everything is much bigger in this game. The character is bigger, the blocks are bigger, everything. This means you cannot fit as much of the game on the screen at a time, so you cannot see as far.

2. There is no map. I use the map all the time in Tererria to find my way around and locate resources. One of the things I like about the map in Tererria is it shows open areas near you, so you can dig towards them. Since this game does not have a map it also does not have this ability. Finding resources is extremely difficult. I have spent hours digging around and ohly found very limited usable resources. Instead Edge of Space has a radar system that you have to craft, and beacons, which you also have to craft. Since it is so hard to find resources it is very difficult to find enough to make these items and so it is difficult to find your way around. Even with the radar, all you get is a little blip on a small radar screen to try and find your way around. This is so much less effective than having a map.

3. So far I have not found any hidden treasures. In Tererria treasure chests and breakable containers are a great way to get resources and gear early in the game. This game does not have these so you have to manufacturer everything yourself. This results in the game moving a lot more slowly.

4. This game does not have biomes like Tererria. For example every Tererria map has desert, jungle, forest and ocean biomes. These go along way to add variety and keep the game interesting. Since this game does not have these it gets boring really quickly. In tererria you also have weather and other events, like blood moons and such. This game does not have anything like that.

5. Weapons suck. The only weapon you have is a gun and it has very limited ammo and has to take time to charge. This is a big pain because if you get attacked by a mob you quickly run out of ammo and have to run away until it charges back up. This makes figinting really difficult and not fun. In addition gun are not good close range, so if the enemies get close you will not be able to hit them. Upgrading the gun is also a slow process. You first have to get enough experience to unlock the plans for a new weapon before you can build it. Since gathering experience is slow it can take a really long time before you are able to upgrade.

6. This brings me to my next dislike. The experience system is completly messed up. There are 18 different categories for experience, and upgrading them depends on which items you pick up. This means you may find a lot of upgrades for furnature, but not for weapons, which has happened to me, and so you have great items to place in your base, but really crappy items to fight with. I like Tererria much better because you only have to gather the materials and you can make anything.

7. You cannot use items directly from your inventory. To use an item, even things like health and other consumable items you first have to put them in your quick bar and then switch to the item and use it. Then when you have consumed all of them it stays in your quick bar with a big red X over it. I would prefer that the item was removed from the quick bar when it was used up. Your quick bar has a very limited amout of space, only 8 slots, so you will be juggling things in a out all the time.

8. Detail screens are split up into 4 different screens. In Tererria if you hit the esc key you see your inventory, weapon, item, and vanity slots and everything else. In Edge of Space you have to hit I for inventory, V for crafting, C for armor and item slots, and L for Experience. The 4 different screen also cover each other up and cannot be moved. So if you try and drap something from the inventory to the armor slot you have to juggle the two screen and make sure they are not covering each other or else it is impossible.

9. The bug reporting system is lousy. When you go to submit a bug you fill out what looks like a standard email form with a place for your email, a subject, and a message. However it is extremely limited in that if you make a spelling mistake or want to go back and clarify something you cannot just use your arrows or mouse and go back to previous text. The only way to go back is to use the backspace key. This means you loose all your typed text up to where you want to change.

All I can say is I am glad I bought this game on sale because if I had paid more than $5 for it I would be extremely upset. Right now I am willing to wait and see if it gets better.

First time I loaded it up I created a char. When I started loading a new world it froze at 75%.
Alt+F4. Tried again. Froze at 75%
Reinstalled and tried again. Froze at 75%.
Verified game. Still froze. Reinstall. FINALY it worked.

Start off with a tutorial covering basics on how to move around the world and open things. Also gives you some info on how to use the UI. I found it pretty difficult to use myself. Then it moves on to the crafting system and has you make a laser pick" out of dirt.... what? Okay whatever. The crafting system is pretty off the wall
date:
I can deal with that.

Then you move on to the combat system tutorial using a gun you made out of dirt again. Some stationary targets then some moving ones... Odd test dummy looking guys running around backwards.

After the tutorial you are dropped on a cluster of floating islands with some pretty rough enemies that you'll have to grind to get items to craft higher teir weapons/armor/tools.

I understand this is still in dev and a lot has to be done. With that. I'll be back when things a a bit more smooth"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlright, im going to make this quick and clear, 1. Dont buy this game. 2. as a player of starbound & terraria, this is absolutely horrible, confusing, and just plain bad, Maybe somebody who hate's their life or has very intresting unique tastes, might find it enjoyable. But from playin like first 20 minutes, Its just horrible from every angle you look at it, my friend bought this game so we could play the game together, but as it turns out, you cant even ♥♥♥♥ing a server normally as other games do.  So i say, if you dont want to waste your money and your life dont buy this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHonestly... I just don't like this game. I love Terraria and Minecraft though. (like Terraria, I don't think it should be compared to Minecraft). The game just doesn't look good in my opinion, is very slow paced, and is just generally boring. I also think the tutorial should be taken out of the game; if you buy this game, you have most likely played Terraria or Minecraft, so you know about crafting and things like that. Some of the fun from these games is learning what to do yourself, and one of the common complaints from the console versions of Terraria/Minecraft is that they even feature a tutorial. Not to mention that it is just FAR to long.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt its current point, this game is not very good. I didn't pay for it, a friend did a while back when it was two for one sale. I played for a bit and I found it almost like terraria, except for less to do. The tutorials are annoying, and there are a couple of bugs that I noticed that make the game unplayable. Until those are fixed, not a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to like this game. But it has so any flaws. The progression is insanely slow and strange, very boring. And the ♥♥♥♥ing griding. Oh god the grinding, I don't mind grinding, but when you give me too much of it, and make the combat quite meh, then make some of the enemies I have to grind ♥♥♥♥ing bullet eaters, it's not fun.
It looks really fun late game, but honestly I don't think it's worth the 10 or so bucks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do not buy this game, period. It says it's in beta, hardly, try more like alpha. Virtually none of the systems are in place. They  list pets as a current feature? It's a droid that circles around you and does nothing. Loads of various armours and weapons? There are 4. Yes I played it for 51 hours, but only because I kept trying to figure out how to do things. For example it says on the wiki page that you need to build an O2 generator to fight exposure. Guess what? It's not implimented.

Do youself a favor and wait for Starbound.
voteText: 14 of 32 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNot worth it in it's current state. This was my first early access" game before I even know what EA was
date: I unfortunately fell for the trap of some cool trailers and the incorporation of some Terraria elements
recommended: making me hope this was a Sci-Fi terraria.\n\nWhile the fundamentals are the same (a 2d minecraft)
hoursPlayed: the execution is just not even close and the polish of the current state of the game is going to make me wait unto 1.0 release. Upon character creation and the 10+ minute load time (I timed it once) you're forced without choice to go through a tutorial which is extremely frustrating after a character whipe. It lays out the very basics which you then shortly forget and feel very lost in the coming gameplay moments.\n\nBuilding and equipment progression seems confusing and not very straight forward
voteText: it's difficult figuring out where to get some of the less common materials without just randomly digging and hoping to hit a vein and what exactly you should be building next. Unless they aren't implemented yet
helpfulPercent: the distinct biomes are non existent. I walked a bit away from my spawn point and jumped down a few ledges and started taking environmental damage. I presume this is a barrier to prevent you from digging a hole straight down (a-la terraria) and gathering the best materials within minutes of starting a new game.\n\nI'll update when the retail version is released but at this time I won't be spending anymore time with this game."
